story: The leftie leader is under intense pressure to come out in favour of a fresh vote which could keep us in the EU.But backbenchers blasted the possibility of a second referendum saying it would drive away Labours traditional voters.Lisa Nandy said a second referendum would result in a No Deal outcome as furious Brexit supporters vote Leave for a second time.And she insisted that ignoring areas like her Wigan seat will ensure Labour cant make it back into power.Ms Nandy, who voted Remain but now wants to respect the  vote, told the BBC: To most people the idea of a second referendum just seems quite absurd.People were asked what they think, you can see from the results that we had here, that very few people have changed their minds andthere is a sht in this area of the country I think its towards No Deal Brexit.I think weve got to wake up to the seriousness not just of what were about to do to the Labour party, but what were about to do the country because I strongly suspect thatthere is a second referendum people here would come out and vote in fairly large numbers and probably vote for No Deal.There is a huge frustration amongst Labour voters who voted Leave in towns like mine to see leading figures from the Labour party out calling for a second referendum before theres been any serious attempt to implement the result of the first.Gloria De Piero, the MP for Ashfield, added that blocking Brexit would wreck the Labour party.She said: This is not just about Brexit. It’s about the future of the Labour party as we know it.Today Mr Corbyns close ally Diane Abbott said Labour would foreground their demand for a second referendum after the EU election disaster.She said: Were supporting a peoples vote strongly now because its the right thing to do and its the democratic thing to do.Labour came third behind both the Brexit Party and Lib Dems in the European Parliament polls.Leave and Remain voters deserted the party because of its flip-flopping Brexit stance.

story: NewsNext Tory leader odds: Profiles of candidates to be UKs next Prime MinisterThe Conservative leadership contest is fast resembling the Grand National as MPs battle it out to replace Theresa May. Heres a full list of the candidates, with odds and profiles for each oneShareCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical CorrespondentDan BloomOnline Political EditorNicola BartlettOliver Milne:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news politics video next-prime-minister-one-next-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics , options :,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,irisClientToken:,externalBrandCSS:true,irisTvEnabled:true,imaVersion:,modularCss:true,nativeAppBanner:true,amazonVideoTagEnabled:true,amazonTagEnabled:true,mvtTests:,video.suppressDates:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics , options :,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,irisClientToken:,externalBrandCSS:true,irisTvEnabled:true,imaVersion:,modularCss:true,nativeAppBanner:true,amazonVideoTagEnabled:true,amazonTagEnabled:true,mvtTests:,video.suppressDates:true""Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTheresa May has announced that she will step down as Tory leader on  June, meaning that the UK will have a new Prime Minister. At least  MPs have already chucked their hats in the ring to replace her in a contest dominated by Brexit. By the end of July we could have a hard Brexiteer Prime Minister who wants to crash the UK out with no deal. Or it could be a more moderate candidate, a continuity May option of entering yet more negotiations with the EU. So who is bidding to replace Theresa May  Hereaposs a full rundown of the candidates with profiles, odds and how much of a True Blue Tory Warrior™ they are. Or click here to see where they all stand on Brexit.  Unlike Mrs Mayaposs election in , where Tory members never voted, this race promises to be the most bruising in years. And just like her election, it will have profound consequences for Brexit - with a hard-right, Hard Leaver likely to take the reins. Under the rules of a Tory leadership race, candidates bidding for the crown must be nominated by two or more fellow Tory MPs. A series of knockout ballots is then held among MPs to whittle down the wide field of candidates to just two.  Those two preferred candidates go to a run-off of the wider Conservative Party, with its , members eligible to vote. The candidate who wins the most votes becomes the leader.  All the Tory leadership contenders Declared openly that they will run Odds retrieved from Paddy Power, May Boris Johnson -   Dominic Raab -   Michael Gove -   Jeremy Hunt -   Andrea Leadsom -   Rory Stewart -   Sajid Javid -   Matt Hancock -   Esther McVey -   Kit Malthouse - not listed on Paddy PowerReported, hinted - or refused to rule outSteve Baker Graham Brady   James Cleverly Penny Mordaunt  Mark Harper David Gauke James BrokenshireLeading Tories who WONaposT be runningAmber Rudd Liz Truss Justine Greening David Lidington Jacob Rees-Mogg Johnny Mercer Tobias Ellwood David Davis Victoria Atkins Ken Clarke Dominic Grieve Tom Tugendhat   Profiles of the candidates Boris Johnson VOTED: Leave TRUE BLUE RATING:    Brexiteer and former foreign secretary Mr Johnson, , has been a leading voice against Theresa Mayaposs Brexit plan - and heaposs been preparing for this for years. The Old Etonian was one of the key players in the  Leave campaign after a last-minute decision to back Brexit. He resigned from the Cabinet in  in protest at Mayaposs plan. He was tipped as a successor to David Cameron but ruled himself out after Michael Gove stabbed him in the back with a last-minute bid for the top job. Since then heaposs lost weight and had a haircut in what many argued was a pre-leadership bid upgrade. Sure enough he confirmed by telling a business conference: Iaposm going to go for it! Selecting the former mayor of London for eight years would enrage Tory Remainers, who believe he is in this game only for himself and his ego. He became notorious for his attention-grabbing offensive comments, when he called black people piccaninnies, said Barack Obama was part-Kenyan and compared the EU to Adolf Hitler. Heaposs also criticised for vast sums of money he rakes in alongside being an MP for speeches and a £,-a-yearcolumn - which was rapped for inaccuracy by the press regulator. Meanwhile, heaposs been rapped for showing a lack of respect to Parliament by repeatedly breaking Commons rules. Supporters say that since splitting with his long-suffering we Marina Wheeler and shacking up with ex-Tory head of press Carrie Symonds, heaposs mended his ways and become more serious. But scores of Tory MPs would vote for Anyone But Boris and a Scottish operation to stop him was nicknamed Operation Arse. Dominic Raab VOTED: Leave TRUE BLUE RATING: .   During his four-month stint as Brexit Secretary, ultra-hard Leaver Dominic Raab suggested he would use leaving the EU to slash business taxes. Now heaposs running for leader heaposs hinted p could be slashed off income tax - cutting billions from the public purse. And that wasnapost all that would anger left-wingers. The -year-old sparked fury in  by saying most food bank users are not languishing in poverty. He claimed: The typical user... is someone who has a cash flow problem. When a disability activist told him people are dying under Tory austerity, he described her calls for cash as a childish wish list. And he put out a pamphlet in  that suggested exempting small firms from minimum wage laws for workers under . Mr Raab positioned himself early on for the leadership, setting out his plans to tackle kne crime with “robust policing” and community work. He also paraded in his home in a cringeworthy interview with his we. And he attempted to outflank hostile competition by addressing claims he used a gagging order, to silence a former colleague who accused him of bullying. Mr Raab told The Sunday Times the claims, which date back to  before he was an MP, were completely ”. Michael Gove VOTED: Leave TRUE BLUE RATING:    The Environment Secretary had a bruising experience in the last Tory leadership race stabbing Boris in the back before finishing third. And he kept his powder dry in the days immediately following Theresa Mayaposs announcement she would quit. But behind the scenes his allies, including Treasury minister Mel Stride, have been approaching MPs in the most unlikely positions to seethey will join his slate. One former Cabinet minister told the Mirror Mr Gove was one of the most likely to be elected. Despite infuriating teachers when he was Education Secretary, and stabbing Boris Johnson in the back for leadership in , the -year-old is seen as a competent media performer and has won plaudits as a campaigner for environmental issues. He has already paraded with his Scottish parents as part of the proxy leadership contest in the party. He was a prominent face in the Brexit campaign, but he isnapost wildly trusted by other figures on the Conservativesapos eurosceptic wing.    Jeremy Hunt VOTED: Remain TRUE BLUE RATING:    Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt was a prominent Remainer in the  referendum. And despite a sht towards Eurosceptic views heaposs now even more prominent - warning deliberately causing No Deal would be political suicide and put Corbyn in No. Mr Hunt has marked himself out as the more moderate candidate against hard Brexiteers but could risk being seen as the continuity candidate for Theresa May. As Health Secretary, Mr Hunt, , fought a long battle with the medical profession over a new contract for doctorsapos working conditions. The -year-old became Foreign Secretary in July following the resignation of Boris Johnson. He chose not to run in the  leadership contest and instead gave his full support to Mrs May, saying it was not the right time to put his hat in the ring.    Andrea Leadsom VOTED: Leave TRUE BLUE RATING:    The -year-old, grammar-school educated former bank executive is about as true blue Tory as you can get. She survived to the final two of the  Tory leadership race, pitching herself as the Hard Brexit, blue alternative to Theresa May with a cringeworthy march in Westminster. But she infamously pulled out after making controversial remarks about motherhood and trying to deny them. She was loyal in public for two years of Cabinet office while furiously working to push towards a harder Brexit in private, through the pizza club of Tory ministers. She played a crucial part in forcing Theresa Mayaposs resignation announcement, resigning from the PMaposs cabinet and blasting her plan hours before the EU elections.    Rory Stewart VOTED: Remain TRUE BLUE RATING:    The Hong Kong-born son of a diplomat, an Old Etonian, once admitted his career gives the appearance he was a spy. The -year-old delivered his own child after a career as a diplomat in the Foreign Office. He was elected MP for Penrith and the Border in  and joined the government in . The International Development Secretary wasted no time after being promoted to the Cabinet in May . He announced his pitch to be PM within hours. He has since travelled to Leave-voting areas such as Barking to put himself out in the faces of the public. Yet his approach - blindly following the PMaposs Brexit deal and saying it might even be worth splitting the party for - has made him wildly unpopular among Tory Brexiteers.    Sajid Javid  VOTED: Remain TRUE BLUE RATING:       It’s widely expected the next Tory leader will be a Brexiteer. That means Mr Javid, , who backed Reman but now supports Leave, would have a real fight on his hands to win round Tory members. He took over at the Home Office after Amber Rudd was forced to quit over the Windrush scandal - and has picked public fights with Mrs May on key issues like immigration and police funding. But his star has fallen over chaotic handling of migrants crossing the Channel. He was accused of stoking tensions by declaring a national emergency to deal with a few hundred migrant crossings over a period of months. Mr Javid, the son of Pakistani bus driver, would be the first non-white Prime Minister. Matt Hancock VOTED: Remain TRUE BLUE RATING: .     The ambitious -year-old entered politics as George Osborneaposs adviser and was in the inner circle of the famously cliquey ex-Chancellor. The parkour- and karaoke-loving Conservative entered Parliament in , Government in  and joined the DCMS in July  after Mrs May took over as Prime Minister. He was swtly promoted to Culture Secretary and then Health Secretary. But he came under fire for accepting thousands from the boss of a think tank which wants to scrap the NHS. Within days of the PMaposs announcement, he somehow found his way onto the Good Morning Britain sofa, where he said of leadership: I think you don’t rule out these things.” Laying out his policy stall beyond Brexit he said he wants to make Britain a high-tech economy exporting to the global middle class. And he said the UK needs to drive up the minimum wage at the same time as slashing tax. Esther McVey    VOTED: Leave TRUE BLUE RATING:   The hardline Brexiteer confirmed she will be running for the Tory leadership with a pledge to slash £billion from foreign aid, and spend it on schools and the police. The former welfare-slasher and rank outsider said: Iaposve always said quite clearlyI got enough support from colleagues then yes I would, and now people have come forward and I have got that support. But former GMTV presenter Ms McVey became notorious among benefit claimants after working as a Minister and later Secretary of State in the Department for Work and Pensions. Her blunt style drew floods of criticism even when she managed to secure limited extra money for cash-starved Universal Credit, and U-turned on a benefit cut for the disabled.  Over the years, she made a number of controversial comments which turned her into a lightning rod for anger about benefits. She was ousted from her Wirral West seat in  after a sustained campaign against her, but ed in George Osborneaposs ultra-safe Tatton seat in . She made clear that under her leadership Britain would leave the EU on October  - deal or no deal. Kit Malthouse    VOTED: Leave   TRUE BLUE RATING:   The former Deputy Mayor of London under Boris Johnson threw his hat in the ring, clearly deciding he could do a better job. The -year-old was an accountant before joining Tory politics and winning the safe seat of North West Hampshire in . He quickly rose through the ranks, joining the DWP as a junior minister before being made Housing Minister where he had the tough task of dealing with fallout from the Grenfell Tower disaster. He ingratiated himself with Brexit-backing MPs by devising the aposMalthouse compromiseapos - a plan for high-tech border checks and other features to solve the Irish border issue. Critics say the plan is unworkable. He openly admitted making le uncomfortable for the homeless as part of a zero-tolerance crackdown when he was on Westminster City Council. Under his watch, the council was accused by one London Assembly member of adopting a ruthless policy towards homeless people that included hosing them out of doorways. Asked in he was behind such a hosing policy, Mr Malthouse replied: We certainly instituted a policy of making le - it sounds counterintuitive and cruel - more uncomfortable that is absolutely right. Still uncleartheyaposll run Penny Mordaunt VOTED: Leave TRUE BLUE RATING:    Recently promoted to Defence Secretary, Penny Mordaunt is a -year-old Royal Navy reservist whoaposs only been an MP since  - but has a rich slew of headlines to her name. From bellyflopping on TV ing show Splash! to slashing billions off benefits and lying about Brexit, sheaposs often been famous - and only sometimes for the right reasons. The daughter of a paratrooper and special needs teacher, who has a twin brother, the Portsmouth North MP went to her local comprehensive. She worked in a factory and as a magicianaposs assistant to save up for Reading University, which she was the first member of her family to go to. The PR supremo was director of communications for the National Lottery, head of campaigns for Diabetes UK, head of foreign press for George W Bush’s  and  election campaigns and chief of staff for former MP David Willetts.    Graham Brady VOTED: Leave TRUE BLUE RATING:    The -year-old, made a Sir in , holds Theresa Mayaposs fate in his hands as chairman of the  Committee. The august body runs leadership challenges in the Conservative Party and could change the rules to force Mrs May out. Heaposs currently its premier diplomat in the Tory war, but could reportedly sacrice his immunity to run for the top job himself. The grammar-school-educated MP for Altrincham and Sale West is a former PR man who turned MP in  and was the chief aide to former Tory leader Michael Howard. James Cleverly VOTED: Leave TRUE BLUE RATING:    The -year-old Brexiteer is a tub-thumping Tory whoaposs not afraid to go into battle on social media. The MP for Braintree has repeatedly got into spats with Labour since taking his job as Tory Vice Chair. Heaposs a boisterous character at social events and in the bars of Parliament, making up for a lack of Westminster experiencewith fierce public loyalty. David Gauke  VOTED: Remain TRUE BLUE RATING:    The pro-Remain Justice Secretary is highly unlikely to be putting his hat in the ring. But there is some suggested he could team up with fellow Remainer Amber Rudd to run on a joint ticket. He also gave a wide-ranging speech on Thursday  May straying beyond the confines of his brief. Mr Gauke took a swipe at populists like Boris Johnson saying: Populism would undermine the United Kingdom.  In the context of the United Kingdom, right-wing populism means English nationalism. The biggest problem with populist policies is that too often, they’re just plain wrong. Big hitters who ruled themselves out Amber Rudd VOTED: Remain TRUE BLUE RATING:    Amber Rudd was previously seen as a favourite to replace Mrs May. But as the party has drted to the right the moderate Remainer Ms Rudd had fallen out of favour. She was forced to quit as Home Secretary during the Windrush scandal. But after eurosceptic Esther McVey quit the government, remain-supporting Ms Rudd, , ed to government as Work and Pensions Secretary. She has a tiny majority in her seat of Hastings and Rye, which would make her vulnerable to any co-ordinated insurgency from local Labour backers. The Work and Pensions Secretary gave a wide-ranging speech on  May that called for a st Century approach to work in what many will see as a pitch for the Tory leadership. She said I hope a softening of benefit sanctions show her credentials as a so-called aposOne Nationapos Tory. And she admitted sanctions may have damaged the Tory brand, saying: If there has been damage I hope we can reverse that.  She dodged questions on whether she would throw her hat in the ring for the Tory leadership, saying: “I’m committed to the DWP”. But she later pulled out accepting the Tory party would want someone fully behind Brexit. Liz Truss  VOTED: Remain TRUE BLUE RATING:    The Chief Secretary of the Treasury is about as right wing as they come when it comes to economics. The -year-old also loves to tell a joke and hasnapost really hidden her ambition to one day hold the top job. She even posed in Westminster for a photo shoot and an interview with the Sunday Times, calling for £bn to be spent on tax cuts. And she appeared in a series of hair-raising photos with wide-bottomed trousers before giving a speech that ranged far beyond her brief. But disappointing performances in high profile jobs like her time a Justice Secretary left some MPs questioningshe has what it takes for the top job. She voted to Remain in the referendum - and since said she would change her mind and became a born-again Brexiteer. But she dropped out saying the leader had to be someone who voted Leave in .

story: NewsPoll shows most people want Britains railways in public ownershipPublic ownership of Britains railways is just the ticket, a poll findsShareCommentsByMark Ellis:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsA Virgin train stands at Euston station in London "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA new poll shows most people believe that Britain’s railways would be better value for moneythey were publicly owned. And the majority of the public are opposed to the rail industry’s plans for increased competition on the railways with rival firms running routes in direct competition with each other. The Survation poll of , adults for the anti-privatisation group We Own It also found people’s trust in the railways would improve or stay the samethey were brought into public ownership. Some % said their trust would improve or stay the same.they were brought into public ownership. A total of % said privatisation had been a partial or total failure, with only % saying it had been a success with % saying they don’t know. Most, %, said rail fares would be cheaper under public ownership with % saying they would be more expensive and % don’t know. And % say railways should be run in the public sector, with % saying they should be privately run and % don’t know. The poll - carried out earlier this month - found % of people think that private train firms don’t have their best interests at heart. Just % support plans from the Rail Delivery Group, which represents rail firms, for increased competition on the railways. The RDG has been calling for Open Access Rail, where rail companies would compete in delivering services on the same route. The new poll provides an insight into public attitudes towards rail privatisation before the government’s consultation on the running of our railways closes later this week. It found that a majority of the public believe the railways would be better value for moneythey were publicly owned - % of people believed that value for money would be better, compared to just % who thought it would be worse. Ellen Lees, of We Own It said:“Private rail companies have been lobbying hard for more private involvement and increased competition on our railways. “This new poll shows just how out of touch the rail industry is. The public doesn’t want more competition, they want a railway they can trust, with cheaper fares that provide good value for money. “This is only possiblethe railway is brought into public hands. After endless delays, cancellations and crowded trains, people are sick and tired of privatisation. “So it’s absolutely vital that with the Williams Rail Review coming to an end, Keith Williams makes the right call on the future of our railways.” The government’s consultation is part of the Williams Rail Review, which closes at the end of May. Former British Airways boss Keith Williams, who is heading the review, has said that the current franchising model on our railways has to come to an end, and will publish his recommendations for the future of the railways later this year. The polling comes just a week after consumer watchdog Which  found that rail passengers last year suffered the worst train delays and cancellations since records began. Commuters lost four million hours on delayed trains last year -equivalent to .m passenger journeys - the worst since . Mick Cash, general secretary of the RMT transport union,said: “This poll is just the latest evidence that the general public are sick to death of more than two decades of the privatisation racket on Britain’s railways.

Candidates for Tory leader are lining up to back a hard exit in a pitch to the partyaposs , voting members. Some are fighting against crashing out of the EU without a deal - with Jeremy Hunt branding the plan suicide.But none are fighting to stop Brexit altogether, and none are fighting to hold a second referendum. Whoever wins the Tory leadership contest will be in  Downing Street by the end of July, and try to put their strategy in place over the summer.  That means they will have a massive impact on how we leave the EU on October , or whether we do at all.The EU could offer an extension beyond Halloween , or Parliamentary gridlock could force a general election.Britainaposs electoral system means we vote for MPs, not a PM - who whoeveraposs in power can steer Brexit without an election by you, the public. Instead the nationaposs policy looks set to be decided by the , Tories who vote in the leadership contest. So what are the candidatesapos positions on Brexit  And how likely are they to crash us out without a deal  Weaposve profiled their positions below - carefully finding comments theyaposve made since coming out for leadership.  Boris JohnsonHARD BREXIT RATING: .  The frontrunner declared heaposs prepared to crash out of the EU with no deal on October . We will leave the EU on October , deal or no deal, Mr Johnson said in May . To get things done you need to be prepared to walk away. But behind the scenes heaposs been less hardline, telling moderate MPs his preference is still a negotiated exit. One insider in his camp told the Mirror: He knows that no deal would be damaging. Butyou want to renegotiate youaposve got to keep it on the table. The problem for moderate Tory MPs, members and the public is this - which Boris Johnson should they believe  Leadership rival Rory Stewart compared him to liar Pinocchio, saying Borisapos no deal promise went back on pledges he made in private. And heaposs famously chosen his views opportunistically, coming out for Leave in  at the moment of maximum impact despite writing an article for each side. He did however burnish his Brexiteer credentials by quitting Cabinet in protest at Theresa Mayaposs deal. Dominic RaabHARD BREXIT RATING: .  The former Brexit Secretary backs leaving without a deal on October  -thataposs what it takes. He has said Britain should be getting a fairer deal and he would prefer to leave with a renegotiated deal. But he added the UK must calmly demonstrate unflinching resolve to leave in October - at the latest. Critics fear his hardline views will make him more likely to walk out of negotiations with the EU. That would plunge the UK into no-deal in October, or could force a general electionMPs revolt against the government. Mr Raab walked out of the Cabinet in November in protest at Theresa Mayaposs deal and has said itaposs time for a new direction. Jeremy HuntHARD BREXIT RATING:  The Foreign Secretary has said pushing for No Deal Brexit would be political suicide and could make the Conservatives extinct. He added MPs could force a general election against any Prime Minister who tried - putting Jeremy Corbyn in Downing Street by Christmas.The comments, in May , are the latest stage in a long run flip-flopping opinions from Mr Hunt. He voted Remain in  but later tried to appeal to Tory Brexiteers, comparing the EU to the Soviet Union and branding himself a born-again Brexiteer and insisting no deal is better than no Brexit. In reality though, few believe he will choose a course he himself has said we would regret for generations.Instead he claims the solution is to change the Withdrawal Agreement Theresa May agreed with the EU in a new round of talks.Thataposs despite the fact the EU has repeatedly said it will not reopen the -page Withdrawal Agreement, which was finished in November  and has been blocked by MPs ever since. He put his le at risk to smuggle reports out of the city. Paul was even called to give evidence when Slobodan Milošević was tried for war crimes. He won awards for his work and now, almost  years later, he has ed to the city where he is a celebrity. Twenty eight years ago I said a tearful goodbye to Dubrovnik. I had spent almost a month in that stunning walled city as a besieging army threatened to do it irreparable damage. It was  and the country that was Yugoslavia was turning on itself. Croatia had declared independence and the Serbian dominated regime in Belgrade was extracting revenge with an attack on the city that brought in much of Croatiaaposs income through tourism. A city that was a UNESCO world heritage site.    By slipping past a naval blockade my ITN team had entered Dubrovnik and placed ourselves with the local population on the receiving end of one of the most one sided conflicts of recent times. Dubrovnik came under attack from land, sea and air with its defence left to a motley citizens army, many of its volunteers hotel workers and tour guides . As the weeks passed and the assault intensied we became the only international TV crew to remain and our efforts to show the outside world what was happening seemed to turn into a personal battle with the besieging forces. Initially we were able to use the local television station to send my reports via satellite to London until successive days of targeted bombing destroyed its transmitter and mast. For several days we then successfully transported cassettes containing our reports on speedboats that left Dubrovnik after nightfall and attempted to slip past the gunboats patrolling the approach to the port. That strategy ended when a speedboat was shot up and the skipper wounded.    Our most signicant report which included cameraman Nigel Thomsonaposs shocking footage of wire-guided missiles being fired into the old town was eventually smuggled out by the remaining members of my team on a ferry boat requisitioned to evacuate women, children and neutrals during a brief ceasefire. Nigel and I stayed on in Dubrovnik for another  days but we would not be as busy or challenged again. Our pictures being broadcast around the world coincided with the besieging guns falling silent. Our Croatian hosts believed the two events were linked and it was on that basis we finally said an emotional goodbye to people who had helped keep us alive on our regular visits to the front line, some of whom had not lived to see the ceasefire. There is an old saying You should never go back and for more than a quarter of a century that is the way I thought about Dubrovnik. The world had moved on and indeed so had I.  From Croatia the war correspondents circus had rolled on, to Bosnia, Kosovo, Albania, Chechnya, another Gulf War and Afghanistan until eventually I retired my flak jacket. Whyand risk a special memory  Last month ITVaposs On Assignment programme asked me to make a film about Dubrovnik in  through the eyes of someone who has seen its darker days. I agreed and soon discovered not all memories fade and there are still places where our industry is associated with more than fake news. As part of the On Assignment filming I had arranged to interview Dubrovnikaposs mayor Mato Frankovic to talk about his controversial strategy of reducing the number of cruise ships to counter overcrowding in the old town.  He asked could I drop into the town hall for a pre interview coffee and chat and warned there might be a member of the local press present. In fact I walked into a room full of TV cameras and microphones and a full blown press conference in which the first question was How does it feel to be back in the city you helped to save   The Mayor presented me with a special award as a Defender of Dubrovnik and that evening all three national TV channels and local programmes featured myand long excerpts from our  smuggled report, saying it had resulted in pressure from Washington and Moscow on then President Slobodan Milosevic to rein in his generals. Throughout our stay in Dubrovnik we were regularly approached by residents who just wanted to say thank you. One elderly gentleman insisted on calling me The Priest and went on to say ITN had sent outthe gospel of truth during the worst of times, independent eye witness accounts they came to trust and rely on as they were re-broadcast on local television. It was an altogether humbling and reassuring experience with the best moment coming when we visited a school to talk to sixth formers about the views of a new generation of citizens. They told us they had been shown all our  reports in their history lessons as the only reliable non-propaganda source of information from that time. What a wonderful thing to hear and what a reaffirmation of the role of honest eye witness journalism at a time when it has become increasingly dficult and dangerous to achieve.Paul’s ‘Return to Dubrovnik’ is one of three reports to feature on tonight’s On Assignment - ITV .pm

But for years rumours have circulated about cameras - saying, for example, that donapost actually work or that there are ways to avoid getting points on your licence. These  things are often said about speed cameras, and speeding in general - are they all true  Road safety charity Brake has been speaking to our sister site Gazette Live , about the truth behind some of the most popular claims. Letaposs take a look at what they said:    . Not all speed cameras work, some are switched off - True A Brake spokesman for Brake said: “Various Freedom of Information requests have revealed that some speed cameras are not fully operational in the UK. “Brake fully supports the use of speed cameras, and would encourage theto use of any cameras that have been turned off. Speed cameras are proven to reduce speeding, and can catch far higher numbers of speeding drivers than traffic police with mobile cameras. . You have to be speeding at least % of the limit plus mph, to get caught - FalseThe law states that a driver can receive a speeding ticket as soon as they exceed the speed limit on a road, eventhat is only by mph. However, guidance provided by the NPCC , suggests that officers do not seek prosecution of a driver until they have exceeded the speed limit by %, plus mph.    Brake says: “It is important to note this guidance is not legally entrenched, and that officers have the discretion to act outside it – drivers should be aware that this guidance also does not mean that they can break the speed limit legally. . If you drive really fast, you wonapost trigger the camera - False Nonsense. The only way to avoid triggering the camera is to stick within the speed limit. . Speed cameras must be painted yellow to be legal - False The Government wants all speed cameras in England painted yellow. Butyouaposre caught on a grey one before that happens, tough - the offence is still valid.    . Average speed cameras donapost really work and thataposs why some people ignore them - False The spokesman from Brake said: “Average speed cameras are an effective way to prevent dangerous driver behaviour. “They are particularly beneficial as they enforce limits over a longer stretch of road, preventing law-breaking drivers from being able to speed up again immediately after passing a camera. . You must be notied within a certain amount of time for it to be valid - True Brake says a driver caught by a speed camera, rather than a police officer, must be sent a Notice of Intended Prosecutionwithin  days. The notice goes to the inidual the vehicle is registered to. . You can request a speed awareness course - False Those eligible for a course will be notied by police. If you havenapost been offered one, forget it.  . You can do a speed awareness course more than once - Sometimes true Drivers caught speeding for a second time may be able to do a second course, dependent on the severity of the offence. But this canapost be within three years of the first speed awareness course, according to guidelines. . If you get a speed awareness course, you donapost have to declare it on your insurance - False Brake says: “Drivers who fail to reveal that they have undertaken a speed awareness course, who then later make a claim to their insurance provider, may find that their policy is invalid. Information on whether a driver has taken a speed awareness course is held by local police forces. . story: NewsUK weather forecast: Brits to bask in C - will the heatwave hit your area The Met Office says June will begin with the hottest weather of the year so far - but only in parts of the UK - as the conditions trigger a "thunder fever" warningShareCommentsByChris kitchingCatherine Wylie:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video temperatures-could-up--degrees-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News , options :,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,irisClientToken:,externalBrandCSS:true,irisTvEnabled:true,imaVersion:,modularCss:true,nativeAppBanner:true,amazonVideoTagEnabled:true,amazonTagEnabled:true,mvtTests:,video.suppressDates:true,info:,article:,info:,],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News , options :,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,irisClientToken:,externalBrandCSS:true,irisTvEnabled:true,imaVersion:,modularCss:true,nativeAppBanner:true,amazonVideoTagEnabled:true,amazonTagEnabled:true,mvtTests:,video.suppressDates:true""Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Britons are set to bask in sizzling summer-like heat with highs that could hit C this weekend - but the scorching weather will only be enjoyed in parts of the country. The Met Office is predicting a balmy start to June with temperatures set to be hotter than traditional sun destinations including Barcelona and Ibiza in Spain, and glamorous Saint-Tropez in the French Riviera. After a few more days of wet and cool weather, it will become increasingly warm and humid from Saturday, bringing the hottest temperatures of  so far.But it has triggered thunder fever fears as high pollen counts threaten to cause deadly asthma attacks. The best weather is expected in central and southern parts of the UK - but how warm will it be in your area    See below for our guide to how warm it will be in your region.Met Office spokesman Grahame Madge said there remains uncertainty on the range of temperatures as forecasters wait for the warm air to arrive. The warmest weather could be enjoyed in places such as Norwich, north London and places away from the coast in the south-east. Temperatures could hit C on Saturday and possibly C on Sunday as June gets off to a brilliant start. But the heat wonapost be felt across the country.  Some places will see closer to average temperatures along with cloud cover and rain. Scotland Highs of about C are expected in the far north of Scotland, and -C from Aberdeen through to Edinburgh. Much of Saturday looks dry and bright but rain is expected later, and it will linger into Sunday. North East England Drier and brighter on Saturday with highs around C over the weekend. Rain is likely on Sunday afternoon. North West England Some brighter spells are possible on Saturday and it will turn increasingly warm and humid before rain arrives on Sunday. Temperatures in Manchester will be C on Saturday and C on Sunday, and it will be C in Liverpool on Saturday and C on Sunday.  Northern Ireland Belfast will see highs of C with rain in the forecast in Northern Ireland on Saturday and Sunday. Saturday will get off to a bright start before rain arrives in the afternoon. Yorkshire and Humber Brighter in the east of this region, particularly on Saturday where warmer with lighter winds, the Met Office said. Temperatures will peak at about C on Saturday and Sunday. East Midlands Saturday will brighten up with lighter winds, and it will feel warm in any spells of sunshine. The Met Office said highs of C are likely on Saturday, followed by C on Sunday.  West Midlands Saturday will be dry and sunny, and it will feel increasingly warm and humid. Highs of C on Saturday and C on Sunday are expected in Birmingham, but rain could fall in parts of the West Midlands from Sunday afternoon. Wales Saturday will be generally sunnier and increasingly warm and humid. Temperatures will peak around C on Saturday and C on Sunday through most of Wales. East of England This is one of the regions where the hottest weather is expected - potentially C on Saturday and C on Sunday. Norwich is the most likely candidate. The Met Office said: Brightening up with lighter winds on Saturday, becoming largely sunny and very warm, locally hot.  London and South East England Scorching conditions are also expected in this region - possibly C on Saturday and C on Sunday, with London the most likely candidate. The warmest temperatures are expected away from coasts. South West England It wonapost be as warm here as the east or south-east, but it will feel humid. Temperatures of about C are likely on Saturday and Sunday with lingering cloud. What is the Met Office saying  Mr Madge said: The indication is that we could see highs of C , isolated highs of around C, on Saturday, and the most likely candidate places for those would be places like Norwich, north London, those sorts of areas away from the coast, but in the south-east corner of the UK. And on Sunday we could see highs of C , even possibly C. So Sunday looks very much as though itaposs going to be a warmer day than Saturday. So we have got that warmth coming through. Once this warm front, and the air behind it, starts to pull across the UK then we will see temperatures starting to rise. UV levels and pollen counts will be high.  Scattered thundery showers may break out on Sunday with cooler fresher conditions already in the northwest spreading southeast to most,not all parts by Monday, the Met Office said.But the hot and humid conditions will lead to higher pollen counts, causing problems for asthma and hay fever sufferers, and triggering thunder fever fears.Thunder fever - a sort of extreme hay fever - occurs when there are thunderstorms and a dangerously high pollen count These storms can absorb pollen grains and cause them to explode into tiny particles that are breathed in. Dr Andy Whittamore, Clinical Lead and GP at Asthma UK, said: “The deadly combination of hot weather, widespread thunderstorms and rising levels of grass pollen this weekend could put more than three million people with asthma at risk of a potentially fatal asthma attack. When pollen is in the air it can inflame people’s airways, triggering asthma symptoms. Stormy weather can make it worse as it breaks the pollen into much smaller particles, which are then inhaled more deeply into the lungs.  “If you have asthma and are already noticing more symptoms because of hay fever, such as coughing, a tight chest or breathlessness, make sure you keep your blue reliever inhaler with you at all times. Take hay fever medicines and your preventer inhaleras prescribed. Sleet and snow showers possible Mr Madge said conditions have been quite cool and there is a possibility of sleet and even snow showers in the Scottish Highlands mid-week. Parts of England could see a frost in isolated areas on Tuesday night and the next few days. There will be a fundamental change once the warm front, known as tropical maritime air, starts to draw the warmer air across the UK, Mr Madge said. He added: , for example, some parts of England could see a frost before this warm front starts to work its way across. Weaposre expecting its arrival overnight so probably getting into the western parts of Britain by just after midnight.  And then it will work its way across, reaching all parts of the UK by later in the week and the weekend. UK hotter than Ibiza According to the Met Office website, Barcelona and Ibiza will see highs of C on Sunday, while St Tropez is expected to reach C. Bookmaker Coral makes this June - to be the hottest since records began. Some forecasters have claimed June could bring an extended heatwave, but the Met Office said it is too early to predict. Cooler, changeable conditions are likely across the UK during the first week of the month. Periods of wet and sometimes windy weather are likely to batter many areas, with occasional thunderstorms with heavy rain. The driest and warmest weather through the first week of June is expected in the south and east. The middle two weeks of June could bring a relatively settled weather picture across the country, the Met Office said. But it warned that thunderstorms and heavy rain could be triggered by warmer day time temperatures, and a low pressure area could bring longer spells of rain and strong winds. Temperatures will be near normal or warm overall for June, the Met Office said. Met Office five-day weather forecastTuesdaySunshine and showers today, these most frequent and heavy across eastern and central parts, where a rumble of thunder is possible. Elsewhere it will be largely dry and sunny with just the odd shower.Tuesday nightShowers gradually fading through the evening to leave a dry night for many and turning chilly. However, more persistent rain will gradually spread into Northern Ireland, Wales and southwest England.WednesdayCloud and rain will slowly spread east with some heavy bursts possible. Grey skies for many in the afternoon with drizzle. However, sunshine and showers are likely in northern Scotland.Thursday to SaturdayLargely cloudy on Thursday and Friday with outbreaks of rain, mainly in the north and west. Long sunny spells in many sheltered central and southern areas. Increasingly warm and humid.

story: NewsHow to make the perfect first impression in just two secondsTo celebrate the launch of the new Goodfellas campaign Made with Respect, body language expert India Ford has shared her tips to making the perfect first impressionShareCommentsByZoe ForseyAudience Writer:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsYou dont have long to make an impression "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIt takes just two seconds for someone to form a first impression of you. The seven-month-old pooch was left abandoned in a ditch on a side road in Chainat, central Thailand, on Saturday. Luckily, a cyclist spotted the puppy thrashing around as he rode past. The terried puppy had thick black duct tape wrapped several times tightly around her jaws preventing her from eating, drinking, or breathing properly. The cyclist called police and nearby residents to help rescue the dog.  Footage shows volunteers placing a grilled chicken skewer by bushes in a bid to lure the distressed puppy out. They spent about  minutes looking around before the hungry brown Aspin traced the smell of the meaty chicken. Villagers had to approach the dog from behind and covered her head gently before they removed the tape from her mouth.    As soon as the rescuer took off the tape, the puppy quickly ran away into the field while the group cheered each other for saving the stray dog. Resident Apichet Somboon said: We never saw her around before and she didn’t seem to know where she was, so we believed that someone had been cruel and tied her mouth and randomly dumped her here. Luckily, we found her just in time or  she may be starving to death. We wish we could feed her before she ran off, but at least we were very happy to see that she was still healthy.  Police in the Baan Kuay district are now investigating to try and find the owner of the animal. Anyone found guilty of of abusing the dog could face up to two years in prison. A spokesman said: We have spoken to citizens in the area but nobody knows who owned the dog and nobody saw anything suspicious. Those who carry out cruelty to animals without reasonable cause shall be liable to imprisonment for a term not exceeding two years or a fine not exceeding , Baht or both.

title: sailors stranded ship 30 months
story: NewsSailors stranded on ship for  MONTHS after it was abandoned by ownerThe sailors are stuck on a ship in the Port of Quebec in Canada for two and a half yearsShareCommentsByMilo Boyd:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsThe MV Ethan has been anchored for  months "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA pair of veteran sailors have been stranded on an anchored ship that was meant to set sail two and a half years ago. For the past  months Vyacheslav Borshchevskij and Richard Thompson have lived together on the MV Ethan in the Port of Quebec, Canada. They joined a crew ready to sail the boat after Bahamian company DD Maritime bought it from the Quebec-based Groupe ​​​​​​Desgagnés in the summer of  for more than ,in cash. A year later the new owners ran into financial trouble leading most of the crew to leave, CBC reported.    But not -year-olds Mr Thompson and Mr Borshchevskij, who decided they would wait on board until theyaposre paid what they say theyaposre owed - a combined ,Mr Borshchevskij has not seen his we and family since he left the Ukraine to fly to Quebec City in Canada a few days before Christmas . Mr Thompson has not seen his son since he left the Bahamas when the boy was five. Heaposs soon to celebrate his ninth birthday.    Due to legislation recently passed in Canada, ownership of abandoned vessels goes directly to the government, which would leave the men unable to get their wages back. Mr Thompson told CBC: How can we go home to our families with zero dollars  Itaposs an embarrassing situation. We basically kept the ship alive, because we know the ship is worthlesswe let it go,you donapost keep the electricity going, the radios warm, the water running through the pipes so they donapost freeze, The unlikely couple have learned to live together, taking turns to cook and occasionally leave the ship to get groceries.    Earlier this year a judge ordered the -year-old boat be sold. On May  it was handed to a new owner infor , , signicantly less than the men say they are owed. According to Mr Thompson there is no mention of either of them in the court ruling. Weaposve been forgotten, he said. The pair have filed a note of protest to the federal court in a bid to be the first creditors paid.    Mr Borshchevskij said he is dreaming of hugging his grandchildren, going on vacation and renewing his professional certication once he is off the ship. Mr Thompson expressed doubts whether he could face his family after paying to keep the MV Ethan working. One of the owners of DD Maritime, Chuck Deal, told CBC News: We are going to pay whatever bills and the crew. We are waiting for extra funding. It might take us a few months. A spokesman for DD Maritime said: Monies have been sent monthly for the crew also we planning on paying the balances as soon as we get the financing deal completed. We have never abandoned the vessel we were overwhelmed with the port bills and needed to get financing which took us longer than expected.

title: dundee look to make manager announcement after interviewing three candidates
story: Dundee will look to finalise the appointment of their new manager in the next few days.The Dee have now interviewed at least three candidates – Jim Goodwin, James McPake and Kenny Miller – and are close to making the final decision over who should be offered the post.That could be done in the next  hours.And unless another contender emerges, it looks to be a choice between Alloa boss Goodwin and Dens youth coach McPake.Former Ross County boss Derek Adams had been in the running but ruled himself out at the weekend.He revealed he had been approached by Dundee with a view to being interviewed but declined the opportunity.Adams did not outline his reasons, other than to say the job at Dens was not one he would consider.After also missing out on the opportunity to interview Inverness Caley Thistle boss John Robertson last week, when the Highland club refused permission for him to be spoken to, the field has narrowed considerably.Dundee, though, are known to be happy with the quality of the men they have interviewed.Meanwhile, former Dens defender Darren O’Dea has agreed a move to Lowland League champions East Kilbride.The -year-old recently announced he was retiring from playing full-time football at the end of his Dundee contract.O’Dea was announced as Motherwell’s U  coach last week but the one-time Celtic player will continue to play for Kilby, who lost the pyramid play-off semi-final to eventual winners Cove Rangers.“I’ve agreed to go down and help East Kilbride. I have lived in East Kilbride for  years and they are a club I know well and they are desperate to go up into the leagues. It is a big town and I can see a bright future for them,” he said.O’Dea, however, said that his new coaching post with the Steelmen is his priority.He added: “I’ve already done wee bits of work towards next season and I’m really looking forward to it. One thing I’m certain on is that I want to be a manager but not for a long time.“The workload of a manager is massive. Coaching the team is probably the easiest part and I can’t even do that just yet.“I am very clear that I don’t see going from playing to coaching as natural. So I’m starting at the very beginning and I know I am a long way from stepping into a manager’s shoes.”

title: letters week 06
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSirWe would like to take this opportunity to thank all of those who have either given or offered assistance and support to my family following the fire at our home on the night of January , and a special thanks to the emergency services that attended.Anyone who was present either at the time or who has seen the remains will appreciate the level of destruction wrought upon our home and the contents within, however, as noted in this paper last week, all of us were unharmed and have been provided with accommodation nearby.The support given by friends, work and the wider community has been truly humbling, and as a family we thank you all and look forward to ing to our home, hopefully sometime next year.Thank you,Alan and Gillian Pitman, The Old Church, ArdrishaigSir,I must commend our MP Brendan O#Hara on his vision and wisdom on his recent fact-finding trip to the Faroe Islands to see first hand how The Faroese inter-connect their islands with  subsea and through mountain tunnels.This common sense approach guarantees safe connectivity   in any weather providing confident travel which is the least the people of Mid Argyll, Kintyre, Islay and Jura should expect. This area of Argyll is the most fragile in the region. The people of Argyll, businesses and visitors deserve no less.Forget the squandering of £m on unreliable, mitigation measures trying to justy a flawed decision made many years ago to use the Old Military Road as a ersion which has failed on many occasions and now has a landslip between the two roads. Forget the expensive excavation of pits by the A rather use the cuttings into the hillside to form a two lane road protected with a flow over canopy with closed outer edges at the four problems gullies. If the contractors on the present scheme can work without any road closures then the flow over canopy option would not lead to closures as many officials and some politicians claim.This is a red herring postponing #a proper solution#. When this is option is completed it will save on the expense of manning the ersion route involving - personnel and - vehicles, replacing expensive nettings, delays whilst the farmer clears his animals and collect his fees. A scandalous waste of public money. Solve The Rest Landslides and stop wasting on mitigating measures.Like Brendan O#Hara I#m neither an engineer or geologist but both of us are blessed with plain common sense. If the Faroese can build a tunnel at £.m per kilometre surely a simple open sided m canopy would cost considerably less. In  at Dawlish .km of double tracked railway and .km of sturdy seawall was built at a cost of £m in eight weeks. Why have we in Argyll after nine years, four dferent Transport Ministers and £m spent and still have no guaranteed safe passage   on The Rest and Be Thankful Follow the Argyll Advertiser#s campaign #Invest in the Rest#. Transport Minister Michael Matheson, Transport Scotland and our Government must abandon their obsession with mitigation measures and fund a permanent solution. We demand no less.Sir,Calls for assurances that the Rest and Be Thankful section of the A will be improved to resist future landslides were made during a session of Transport, Infrastructure and Connectivity questions in the Scottish Parliament.I quizzed transport secretary Michael Matheson, about what was discussed at the last meeting of the A Taskforce in November , and asked what assurances the Cabinet Secretary could give to local residents and businesses who rely on the A being open at all times.The Rest and Be Thankful was closed off for nine days in October  following the largest landslide in a decade, forcing road users to either take a major ersion, or to use the Old Military Road during certain hours of the day.A number of petitions were created during the period of the incident, including one by myself, calling for a permanent solution to the Rest and Be Thankful.The transport secretary said that the meeting was #full and frank#, and that there would be a #review of the potential for additional landslide mitigation measures at the Rest and Be Thankful#, and that this would be discussed at the next A Taskforce meeting in March .There was also a commitment that Argyll and Bute would be #prioritised# in the next Strategic Transport Projects Review.I welcome the assurances by the transport secretary that there will be a review of any additional measures for the Rest and Be Thankful, and that Argyll and Bute will receive priority at the next Strategic Transport Projects Review.Donald Cameron, MSPReserve forcesSir,Last issue#sletter raising concerns about the UK government’s proposed use of the army’s reserve force in the event of a no-deal Brexit is timely.In case anyone out there still thinks a no-deal Brexit is a good idea it’s worth noting that the legal authorityof Reserve Forces Act  allowing the Secretary of State to take this step requires him to establish that it is necessary #for the alleviation of distress or the preservation of le or property in time of disaster or apprehended disaster#.Enough said.Frances Roberts, Ardrishaig

title: thought for the week march 22 2019
story: Hannah OHanlonUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowAs a very enthusiastic, though amateur, photographer, I had treated myself to a new and rather expensive camera lens.Usually I purchase an inexpensive skylight filter to protect the lens from scratches or damage.The theory being that it is far easier and less expensive to replace an inexpensive filter than a very expensive lens.However I was intrigued when I began to research the best filter for my requirements.I was being offered a completely clear glass filter for way more than I would normally pay for a simple skylight filter.At first I thought: #Why on earth would I pay such a lot of money for something which is just a piece of clear glass #However when I read the reasons given to purchase this clear piece of glass, I was convinced.The logic was this – why pay a lot of money for a top-class lens, and then put a cheap filter on it Why not let the lens do the job you have paid it to do, and simply protect it with the finest clearest glass you can get.I thought of the words of St Paul who said: #For now we see through a glass, darkly but then face to face: now I know in part but then shall I know even as also I am known.#Somehow my clear glass filter gives me the best image reproduction I can have.In our earthly le, we see Jesus as best we can, perhaps through a skylight filter, but just think that in time there will be nothing to dull our vision and we will see him in all his glory # crystal clear and face to face.

story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSir,This is a short note of thanks to all who made my th birthday party at Chalmers Court such a success.I did not help a great deal by having a bad fall near the bus stop on my way for the morning papers and am lucky not to have broken bones. A bruised and battered face caused alarm on first viewing which gave way to quite a lot of laughter and bold comment.But what a delightful party, laid on by our warden Sheena Stewart and ladies and saw we all had tea, coffee, and home baking, including shortbread and sconesand presents of wine and malt whiskey. What a lovely morning.To all who sent cards for my th, including the community council, the Wednesday Club, the Inveraray Highland Games , my warmest thanks. And many thanks to those who helped me up after my fall and in particular Stuart Campbell of Brambles who took me to the surgery, whose very kind people cleaned me up and sent me on my way to my party half an hour later.And a mention to Take the Floor too on Radio Scotland on Saturday night. Thank you Inveraray and District Accordion and Fiddle Club and Margaret Mather our secretary for this request.So I won#t forget my th in a hurry, but such kindness and friendliness cannot be forgotten ever.My thanks to you all,Niall Iain MacLean, InveraraySir,I read with great interest the letter in the March  edition of the Argyllshire Advertiser from C Rees, Lochgilphead.In addition to all that was mentioned I wonderyour readers are acquainted with the McCrone Report which was written in the s As I’m sure your readers are aware this was when oil had just started flowing from the North Sea. Mr Gavin McCrone was, at that time, a civil servant instructed to write a report on the possible effects of North Sea Oil on the argument for Scotland’s devolution.This quote comes from a letter written, by Mr McCrone, in April : #The Paper was written over a year ago in the weeks immediately before the February  election. This will be particularly apparent on page  where, of course, the ministerial pronouncements referred to relate to the Conservative Government.#So he was instructed to write this report by a Conservative Government but was reporting to a Labour Government.This quote comes from the end of the letter: #When my paper was written it was classied “secret” and given only a most restricted circulation in the Scottish Office because of the extreme sensitivity of the subject.#The report discussed the possibility of Scottish Independence and came to the conclusion: #What is quite clear is that the balance of payments gain from North Sea oil would easily swamp the existing deficit whatever its size and transform Scotland into a country with a substantial and chronic surplus.#Now, this is a very tiny segment from a document that could have changed our history but that’s in the past and we must now look to the future.What is upsetting is thatthis wealth had been invested in an oil fund or more fairly distributed by the  British Government # either Conservative or Labour # there might not, now, be an upsurge in support for separation from Westminster.Wilma Watts, TarbertSir,With Theresa May’s Brexit deal yet again failing to get through the House of Commons and a delay to the date the UK is due to leave the EU, it is clear that we are simply lurching from crisis to crisis.One wonders what good an extension will actually do given the negotiating position of both the EU and the UK. The UK is deadlocked, in terms of its people, Parliament and Cabinet and the likelihood of any semblance of a deal that command the majority of the House of Commons is unlikely. This is especially true given the deep isions within the Tories, both Remainers and Leavers, as well as opposition from the DUP.Given this situation those like myself have long argued that a UK-wide referendum on the deal, a so-called ‘People’s Vote’, with the option to remain in the EU, is the only credible way to break this deadlock. For those who argue that this would damage our democratic process, I am not sure we can slump any lower than the situation we are currently in.As David Davis, the former Brexit Secretary and an ardent Leaver, pointed out before the EU referendum: #If a democracy cannot change its mind, it ceases to be a democracy.#There are few I know who voted for Brexit in the belief it would make them poorer, and it is up to the public to give its view on whether the deal, and more importantly its implications, are what it wants.For once I agree with Jacob Rees-Mogg who previously supported a vote on the renegotiated settlement. A statement he now curiously seems to have forgotten.The Scottish Parliament has led the way in backing a People’s Vote and now that we know the precise nature of the deal, it is up to the public to have its say.Alex Orr, Edinburgh

story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowFurnace folk woke up on Sunday April  to find that their village was ablaze with colour.Pompom trees, bright flowers up the wall of the village hall and colourful birds nesting in the school garden, and many new residents had joined the community in the form of giant purple caterpillars, huge multi-coloured spiders and a rather odd-looking woman with a face painted by Picasso, knitting nonchalantly outside the village hall.Furnace had been truly #yarn bombed#.This unprecedented wool attack was put together by members of the vibrant Furnace Craft Group who wanted to make their very first Furnace Craft Day one to remember, and with the sun coming out to join in the fun the day was a huge hit with residents as well as many other visitors.Inside the hall visitors were able to browse the many colourful and innovative craft stands, including a visit from Travelling Yarns with their mobile pop-up wool shop selling a vast array of Scottish wools. Many visitors also took a seat around the #have-a-go# table to learn more and make their own pompom caterpillar or plant, take up a bit of cross stitch or find out about the art of decoupage – a staple of the immensely popular activity of upcycling, while others took advantage of the opportunity to sit outside the hall enjoying delicious home-made cakes washed down with tea or coffee.Co-organiser Ruth Tott commented: #The idea of the craft day just grew and grew, with one thing leading to another. title: letters to the editor week 18 2
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSir,I read with interest the article in the April  edition of the Argyllshire Advertiser about the council’s autism strategy.I find it strange Councillor Green said the #strategy has reached a draft stage# when an Autism Strategy for Argyll and Bute already exists.It was commissioned by the council, produced in May  and signed off by council members. An implementation plan was produced in December  to cover the years -. Who in Argyll and Bute is responsible for this plan  How many of the outcomes have been achieved As someone who has been involved with autism personally and professionally for many years, I find it extremely disappointing there seems to be an inability by those in authority to get organised enough to address the issues and provide services for autistic people and their families.There is no need for further drafts and consultations.Someone in the authority needs to take responsibility for the existing strategy and implementation plan and get on with it.Maureen Mackintosh, Ardrishaig.Sir,Scotland’s small building firms had a strong start to , in contrast to the UK construction small and medium sized enterprisesector, according to the Federation of Master BuildersScotland.The FMB State of Trade Survey for the first quarter of , the only quarterly assessment of the UK-wide SME construction sector, showed SME workloads declined for the first time in six years.In Scotland, however, there was a jump of  per cent compared with the previous quarter. Thirty per cent of weighted responses were positive, up from  per cent from the fourth quarter of .It is encouraging the Scottish construction industry is bucking the wider Brexit trend with workloads and enquires in rude health. The UK-wide picture is very dferent, with the construction SME sector overall contracting for the first time in six years.Scotland’s good fortune could be due to fewer EU workers being based north of the border compared with other parts of the country, like in London where one in three construction workers are from the EU.Relying less heavily on migrant workers has meant the Scottish construction industry hasn’t fallen foul of thousands of EU workers ing home during the long march to Brexit due to no longer feeling welcome in the UK or sure of their future here.Scotland’s builders, however, must not be complacent. Looking ahead, the First Minister has indicated thatthe UK does leave the EU later this year, she wants a second independence referendum before the next Scottish Parliament election in . This additional political uncertainty, on top of the continued uncertainty stemming from Brexit, could impact on the construction sector in Scotland.The fear is a looming second referendum could test consumer confidence this year and next. For construction SMEs, this is particularly concerning as their prospects are vulnerable to dips in consumer confidence as so much work comes from the private domestic sector.Gordon Nelson, Director of FMB Scotland.Sir,I was joined by my fellow Conservative councillors in Kilmory recently as we discussed atthe numerous challenges facing Argyll and Bute.Ferry sailings, roads, education and the SNP#s late single farm payments were all mentioned.With the SNP hammering local authority spending and cutting our budgets, challenges in delivering services will become more prevalent.Despite this climate of cuts from the separatists, Conservative councillors are delivering for Argyll. This includes extra funding for the Tarbert and Lochgilphead Regeneration Fund, more funding for infrastructure and an increase in roads winter maintenance resources across Argyll.As ever, my fellow Conservatives and I will continue to fight non stop to make sure our rural constituency is not sidelined by this unceasingly urban and separatism-obsessed over centralising Scottish Government.Councillor Alastair Redman, Kintyre and Islands ward.Sir,I photographed this unusual visitor to Kilduskland Road, Ardrishaig, on April . Magpies are not a regular feature in Mid Argyll. We have not seen one in more than  years here.I think I saw a second one, either in pursuit or being pursued.Ron MacInnes, Ardrishaig.PIC:The Ardrishaig magpie, spotted in April. no_aMagpie

title: rusty padlocks no more new owner talks about plans to re open inveraray pier
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsThe new owner of Inveraray#s iconic but neglected pier has plans to re-open it to the public # but only after refurbishment work is complete.The pier has been purchased by the Colonsay-based Byrne family, owners of the nearby Inveraray Inn.Earlier this week company director Geaspar Byrne spoke exclusively to the Argyllshire Advertiser about the reasons for buying the pier and what lies ahead.Mr Byrne said: #I have an interest in Inveraray and want to see it doing well. It is obvious to everyone that the pier not being open is a resource wasted.#Inveraray Pier has been in existence since . Comprising an older stone-built section and later timber structure, it was once a thriving hub for Inveraray#s herring fleet and a popular destination for passenger steamers. It was used by everything from pleasure craft to puffers, with the military also making good use of it over the years.In more recent times it has fallen into disrepair and was closed off to public access in the last decade.#When we heard it was for sale we decided to make a bid,# continued Mr Byrne.#It would have been a shame to see it fall into the hands of someone who would want to use it just as a private pier. It#s about securing its future.#The Byrne family intends to re-open the pier for public use # but Mr Byrne is keen to dampen speculation about the potential future uses for the structure.Before anything  happens, the condition of the stone and wooden sections must be assessed, and reports have been commissioned from engineers and conservation architects.#I don#t want to raise expectation unnecessarily, but the most likely scenario is that we look to re-open the stone pier first of all,# explained Mr Byrne.Repairs would be needed to the stone structure and ironwork. New handrails and safety equipment would be needed along with lighting and basic security measures such as CCTV.Beyond that, the future of the wooden pier looks less certain.refurbishment is not an option, alternatives might include floating pontoons, while the potential for dredging around the pier and harbour might be considered.Through an agent, The Argyll Partnership, the Byrne family has contacted the Clyde Marine Planning Partnership with a view to having Inveraray included in the fledgling Clyde Regional Marine Plan, stressing that the pier #represents a great opportunity to contribute to the economic, social and environmental needs of the Clyde Marine Region#.And the new owners have said that the community council, Inspire Inveraray and others from the area will be fully involved as the redevelopment takes shape. The plans are also said to have the backing of the Duke of Argyll.Mr Byrne concluded: #Hopefully local people will want to help and come forward with ideas.#I don#t want to raise hopes at this early stage, but I hope that buying the pier is a good thing to do.#

title: jake gets his message across to jura
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +viaYOURTWITTERNAMEHERE" title"Tweet this"TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowStrolling along the beach while on an Easter break to her native Isle of Jura, Patsy Boyle noticed a plastic water bottle lying above the high water mark.At first dismissing it as just another piece of marine litter, she noticed something inside the bottle # a piece of paper.The romance of sending or finding a message in a bottle may be fading a little as marine pollution becomes an ever more prominent issue # but for the seven-year-old lad who sent the message, it was a real thrill to discover that it had been found.Jake Curtis was inspired to send his note after reading a story in the Argyllshire Advertiser about a message in a bottle turning up on the shores of Loch Fyne at Furnace.So, on February  this year he set off on his dad#s fishing boat into the Sound of Jura from Carsaig, near Tayvallich.On a piece of paper, carefully sealed in a plastic pouch and with a mobile phone number included, he wrote: #To whoever finds this, my name is Jake. My favourite things to do are playing my X-Box and Nintendo Switch and snuggling with my mum.#I have a sister called Holly and she is six. I have been fishing with my dad and threw this into the sea.#Please let me knowyou find this. Thank you, from Jake.#The bottle floated on the Sound of Jura before Patsy spotted it almost three months later on Knockrome shore, near Craighouse, blown well above the high tide mark by easterly winds.In sharp contrast to the leisurely progress of the original note, Patsy replied to Jake by st century methods using text messaging, telling him she#d found the bottle.Patsy, from London, told the Advertiser: #He was so excited to hear it had been found. We spoke afterwards and it was just delightful.#Jake said: #I really liked going out with my dad and sending the message, and I was happy when it was found.#
