title: Iain Macwhirter  Scotland really is leading the way on climate change  but it won t be a walk in the park
story: Therersquos some doubt, according to the science journal Nature, about just how effective tree planting is as a means of combating global warming. Trees emit chemicals too, and darken the land, thus absorbing heat. But letrsquos not quibble. The Committee on Climate Changewhich inspired last weekrsquos landmark target, is in no doubt that mass reforestation ndash and wersquore talking billions of trees ndash will be one of the major methods of scrubbing CO from the atmosphere.Scottish Greens: How you can help fight climate changeScotland is well placed to deliver on this at least. Those barren hills and glens used to be under a dense covering of foliage. The forests were cleared for agriculture and charcoal in the south, and latterly for sheep and deer in the north. So mass forestation is only restoring the ecological default in Scotland.Nice to know, too, that Scotland, on paper at least, is leading the way on meeting climate change targets, having reduced emissions by a creditable % since . This is better than the UK as a whole, which is itself a world-leader in climate control. Scotlandrsquos abundant renewable energy is going to play a major role in transforming the UK economy.Transport is one of the main areas yet to be decarbonised, and every watt of that green energy is needed to make the switch from petrol and diesel in the next decade. Itrsquos long overdue. The internal combustion engine is th-century technology, horribly complex, unreliable and inefficient. Future generations will be astonished that we allowed our city streets to remain sewers of toxic chemicals.Mind you, the Scottish Government needs to put its foot on the environmental accelerator pedal. It is three years since I wrote a series of articles on electric cars after being allowed to drive some of them around Scotland. There were precious few charging points back then, and therersquos scarcely any more now. Yet, the electrication of transport should be a relatively simple exercise.Every petrol station should be a charging station, every supermarket car park, every school and hospital. Wherever cars congregate, in fact. The good news is that no-one who tries a modern electric car will want to drive anything , because they are faster, cheaper, safer and more reliable.Of course, manufacturing any car uses prodigious amounts of energy too, requires many costly materials and produces toxic waste. Electric cars arenrsquot a solution to climate change, but electrication of transport must be, especially micro-transportation. Every city in Europe seem to be turning to those electric scooters ndash except in the UK where they are illegal. Half of the bicycles sold in Germany now are electric. People are turning naturally to more energy-efficient transport so why not give them a push :Climate clock is ticking and now is time for politicians to fightThe CCC report was rather benign on flying. Yoursquoll be pleased to know that itrsquos not being phased out. This is probably because reducing aviation requires international agreement. However, cuts in air passenger duty seem dficult to justy. The Scottish Government wants APD cut by % to attract more business and tourists to Scotland. But Nicola Sturgeon is going to have to bite the environmental bullet here. The optics are wrong. It looks too much like a middle-class subsidy, even though many working-class people swear by Ryanair.Then therersquos the nuclear conundrum. Scotlandrsquos nuclear power stations account for % of electricity generation ndash a large proportion of our nominally clean energy. But they are old and unreliable and in need of replacement. However, nuclear power stations are regardedas a safety issue following Fukushima. They are also ruinously expensive and damage the environment by producing toxic waste which needs to be stored for thousands of years.The nuclear industry leapt upon last weekrsquos CCC report as a vindication of nuclear as part of the de-carbon equation. Big money is going into painting the atom green. But the prospect of the Scottish Government commissioning a new nuclear plant, given the explosive cost of Hinkley Point C, Englandrsquos first new nuclear power station in decades, seem remote. Renewable energy is much cheaper, joule for joule,it can be brought to grid fast enough. We are in a race against time to seeTorness and Hunterston can be made redundant before they fall apart.There are other issues too. Homes need to be insulated, gas boilers are going to have to go. Wersquore told to keep our home thermostats at  degrees, when most of us donrsquot have them. Itrsquos all expected to cost -% of GDP. But what was remarkable about last weekrsquos much-anticipated report was how doable it all appeared. By comparison with the apocalyptic forecasts of the climate Cassandras, like -year-old school striker Greta Thunberg, the CCC sounded like a walk in the environmental park. Nicola Sturgeon insists that cutting carbon will improve our health and wellbeing and the quality of le. Wersquoll all be happier, cleaner and probably working less in our new habitable planet.I hope shersquos right. There was an air of wishful thinking about last weekrsquos pronouncements. But therersquos nothing wrong with accentuating the positive. The problem with the more alarmist forecasts of Extinction Rebellion, who want net zero by , is that they induce not willingness to change, but a sense of futility and public apathy. If addressing climate change is going to involve banning travel, eating no meat, digging for vegan victory and plunging the economy into a biblical recession, as we close down whole sectors of industry, then people will not buy into it. The Yellow Vest movement was ignited by an environmental tax.Scottish Greens: How you can help fight climate changeIt may well be that the climate change targets are still too conservative. According to the UNrsquos International Panel on Climate Change, CO emissions need to be cut faster to prevent the planet warming by more than .C ndash the new tipping point. But the Scottish and UK governments have consistently outperformed their targets since they started making them seriously over a decade ago. They can do so again.Much of climate hygiene is self-evident. The public are morally signed up to it, and while abandoning their petrol and diesel cars may seem a grim prospect now, in practice it is likely to be a liberation. Most cars spend their lives sitting near a pavement losing value through depreciation. With proper public transport and urban alternatives, everyone wins.Vested interests are always a block on progress, but there is now a remarkable consensus, from the CBI to the GMB, BP to the NFU, the BMA to BMW. Addressing climate change need not take us back to a pre-industrial world of squalor, disease and hardship. The human race isnrsquot over yet.

title: three-months-after-its-launch-how-strong-is-the-pulse-of-the-nations-newest-tv-channel
story: Itrsquos a period in which the pound million channel dedicated to Scotland and Scottish content has, at times, attracted record digital audiences, won a quarter share of Scottish viewers, been the third most-watched channel in Scotland after BBC One and STV, reached more people between the ages of  and  than any other channel in Scotland, gained serious traction on social media and, in the best of its content, made good on its promise to give Scottish audiences programmes they wonrsquot see anywhere  and which deal with the issues and subjects that affect, concern and interest them .But itrsquos also a period marked by a wild iance in audience ratings , by whispered rumours of discontent and in-fighting, by a perceived lack of brand identity and by a barrage of negative headlines either questioning the need to have the channel in the first place or pouring scorn on specic programmes, such as The Nine or Catriona Shearer-fronted gameshow Wonderball.:  years of rock and roll - and all that jazzLaunching BBC Scotland in Glasgow in February, BBC Director-General Tony Hall outlined the aims of the channel. As he saw it, they were to celebrate Scotlandrsquos strengths in arts, comedy, science and ldquothought. To reflect the countryrsquos ersity. To allow audiences ldquoto interrogate the things that matter to them and, along the way, to ldquoreinvent public service broadcasting. BBC Scotland, he stressed, would offer space for discussion and debate alongside opportunities to ldquokick back and have fun. It would be about the country speaking to itself but also to the world. It would be local, national and global.In other words it would be a lot of things to a lot of people. Or it would try to be. So, three months after its glitzy birth and with the numbers soon to roll over to Day  of its existence, how is BBC Scotland bedding in  What do audiences think of it  And how well is it measuring up to Hallrsquos lofty claims Steve Carson, BBC Scotlandrsquos Head of Multi-Platform Commissioning, is predictably bullish about its prospects and its track record. To his mind the station is about trying to take risks, giving a  to ldquoa strong range of voices and communities and doing ldquonew things and dferent things. So far the strike rate is good, he thinks. Among the successes he points to are Getting Hitched Asian Style, a documentary series following a wedding planning company in Glasgow, the opening night screening of Nae Pasaran , and Last Breath, a drama documentary about a North Sea er stranded on the sea-bed.Identying a stand-out is ldquolike naming your favourite child, he says. ldquoBut I think Asian Weddings is something I was pleased to see hellip It was quite straightforward but it got into communities you donrsquot often see and certainly donrsquot often see in that sort of context.For an example of risk-taking that paid off he points to Sink Or Skim, which took a fond look at the World Stone Skimming Championship held annually on the isle of Easdale in the Firth of Lorn.ldquoThatrsquos not a subject many channels would have commissioned, but it was a beautully made piece and it was funny watching it go out and looking at social media because people were going lsquoI canrsquot believe theyrsquore doing something about stone skimming. Is this part of their sport portfolio rsquo. But by the end of it the same people were going lsquoThat was really goodrsquo.Sink Or Skim was a one-off but The Peoplersquos News is a weekly discussion of topical events in which ordinary Scots go in front of the camera and have their tuppence-worth on topical events. Those featured might not have the political contacts of a Laura Kuenssberg, say, but they have something just as important: context. They represent the social and political views of people in a spread of communities distant from London and far removed from the Central Belt. Itrsquos another example of the channelrsquos guiding principle that BBC Scotland should be a  for discussion and debate and again itrsquos a programme that wouldnrsquot have aired anywhere .ldquoWe could have done a dferent version of this channel which would have been a lot less risky and done a lot more of what other channels do, says Carson. ldquoA Scottish version of BBC Four, for example, would have been a less risky proposition. But we already have that, so we felt it was important to try new things, go for harder to reach audiences and deliberately take risks knowing that not all of them ndash in fact many of them ndash wonrsquot pay off. Thats what wersquore about.So which risks havenrsquot paid off ldquoThatrsquos like naming your least favourite child, he says. ldquoI think the programmes that we have originated between pm and pm have had a tough time, but again our medium term strategy was not to originate as much there. The Nine has had ratings which have gone up and down, but wersquove always said thatrsquos a competitive slot. But on a digital channel ndash and wersquore already the biggest non-terrestrial channel in Scotland with a three per cent share, which is well ahead of projections ndash audiences will go up and down across the night and the week.:  years of rock and roll - and all that jazzIf therersquos a lightning rod for criticism, The Nine is it. An hour in , staffed by a team of presenters and journalists that numbers  ndash at least in the publicity shots ndash and fronted by Rebecca Curran and award-winning former ITN journalist Martin Geissler, itrsquos the stationrsquos flagship news programme.A lot rides on its wellbeing and it seems a little peaky. It was reported that on one day in late April viewing figures dropped to just . They picked up the following day, to , but even on April , the first day of the inquiry into the Clutha disaster, they couldnrsquot quite hit . From a first night high of ,, thatrsquos a signicant drop.ldquoThe Ninersquos average is signicantly higher than that figure and its reach, which is really important in news, is reaching a quarter of a million a week, Carson counters. ldquoItrsquos offering something dferent. If you wanted to point at a show which is something we wouldnrsquot have otherwise done, The Nine is it ndash an hour long news and analysis programme which looks at Scotland, the UK and the world through Scottish eyes.So is it simply the right show but in the wrong time slot ldquoWersquoll see. Nine orsquoclock is a competitive slot but there is a demand there and people are turning to it. The appreciation for The Nine is very strong and wersquore finding that across the board. You might get some programmes that donrsquot have huge average audiences but the appreciation is strong.In a front page story earlier this month, London-based broadsheet the Sunday Times quoted a BBC source who called The Nine ldquoa turkey. The same source added: ldquoYou canrsquot have a channel that nobody watches. Journalists like their output to be watched and it wonrsquot be long until some of the channelrsquos main talent head for the door. Another source spoke of a ldquopoisonous atmosphere in the newsroom causing behind-the-scenes tensions which could cause key staff to walk. True or   ldquoThat is not the case, Carson says bluntly.Among the keenest watchers of how BBC Scotland has fared over these first three months is Dr Lisa Kelly, a lecturer in television at Glasgow University.ldquoIrsquove been pleasantly surprised, she says. ldquoI think I probably wasnrsquot holding out much hope at the beginning, primarily due to the budget ndash pound million for programming isnrsquot much to play with in the television landscape.To put the budget in context, the BBC is spending nearly three times that amount on the new EastEnders set. But funding aside, Kelly is excited by the apparent focus on nurturing and showcasing new talent. Shersquos also impressed by the choice of programmes and pleasantly surprised at the internationalism of its outlook. One innovation she particularly welcomes is the Next Big Thing strand, which screens short films such as as Meet Me By The Water by Scots-Asian writer-director Raisah Ahmed.ldquoI think therersquos been quite a range of programming. It seems like they are trying to be erse in terms of their representation. So obviously you have Getting Hitched Asian Style and The Nine, which is trying to tackle current debates around issues of representation. So I think it has been quite successful so far.And does it matterratings are low for some programmes ldquoI donrsquot know that it does this early on. I think itrsquos important that we have access to original Scottish programming at a local and national level.There are other challenges, she thinks, besides ratings. One is establishing the channelrsquos identity. ldquoIrsquom not quite sure what its brand is yet in terms of how itrsquos selling itself. I noticed that before the launch it was targeting young people with this notion of fresh and original ideas, but I donrsquot know whether theyrsquoll be able to sustain that.Another is proving that the bold talk ndash of nurturing young talent, giving voice to dferent groups and communities, taking risks and tackling ersity ndash will be backed by bold actions.Wherersquos the Scottish Phoebe Waller-Bridge, for example  And how embedded is the commitment to ersity and inclusion, to actually hearing new voices and seeing dferent stories rather than it just being rhetoric with no change Theyrsquore questions for which Steve Carson has a ready answer. Sothe Scottish Phoebe Waller-Bridge was out there with a project she was aching to make, is he convinced he would find her and commission it ldquoI hope so. And I think we are finding quite extraordinary talent at all levels and also stretching people who might already have done one thing but are now doing something . Like State Of It, which is Robert Florence [co-writer of sketch show Burnistoun] doing quite a scabrous satirical show. Itrsquoll be coming out in the autumn.There is data which can help, however. A measuring system known as ldquosocial listening can analyse social media responses to any subject and from that gain an insight into how that subject is viewed, expressed as the over-riding emotion associated with it.:  years of rock and roll - and all that jazzBBC Scotland set the algorithms running at launch and four weeks later the results came back. ldquoThe strongest emotion in social listening was surprise, says Carson. ldquoThat was really encouraging. So modern Scotland, outward looking, surprising and focussed on new talent ndash thatrsquos the core identity of the channel. SoBBC Scotland is a keyboard emoji, itrsquos a colon and a zero.Three months ago, the channel launched with a Miracle. Whether itrsquoll need another one to make it sing in the long term is harder to judge. As they probably donrsquot teach you to say in continuity announcer school, watch this space.BBC Scotland: The Good, The Bad And The NineGetting Hitched Asian StyleA behind-the-scenes documentary following Glasgow wedding planners Saffron Events as they prepare for a succession of glamorous weddings, Getting Hitched Asian Style proved so successful that it received a repeat run on BBC One and has been re-commissioned for a second series on BBC Scotland. Produced by the Scottish ision of London-based Firecracker Films itrsquos a good example of the channelrsquos stated commitment to programmes which reflect Scotlandrsquos ersity. Verdict: funny, interesting, occasionally jaw-dropping but ultimately humane.A View From The TerraceBorn out of The Terrace, a long-running podcast, AVFTT is fronted by four young presenterswho sit on sofas and talk engagingly about Scottish football. Refreshingly free of Old Firm bias itrsquos fast becoming a Friday night staple for those fans of the Beautul Game who think subjects such as the on- and off-field shenanigans of Partick Thistle legend Chic Charnley or how Eriskay has one of the best pitches in the world are as worthy of discussion as whorsquoll be the next manager of Real Madrid. Verdict: a great signing.Sanjeev Kohlirsquos Big TalkA weekly show in which the comedian is joined by a  of guests for a ldquosideways look at the big issues of the week, filmed in what looks like the foyer of the BBCrsquos Pacic Quay HQ in Glasgow in front of what looks like a smattering of audience members. ldquoI never in my le want to endure another excruciatingly mirthless hour of supposedly witty commentary on the weekrsquos news, wrote one Herald critic. ldquoIt was so awful the only way to hang on to consciousness was to watch what was happening outside the glass-fronted studio. Less trenchant criticism has concentrated on the showrsquos stfness and its uneven format. Verdict: could do better.WonderballItrsquos probably destined for cult status among Generation Z-ers as an endless source of memes, but in the here and now BBC Scotlandrsquos flagship gameshow hasnrsquot been exactly showered with love. Letrsquos not take it too far, though: Wonderball is not, as right-leaning tabloid the Daily Mail has suggested, the worst show of its type ever aired, eventhat paper might like it to be. But you canrsquot say that those who have pointed out its flaws ndash the somewhat complicated rules, say, or the unintentional snigger value of two young men being instructed to play with the blue balls ndash donrsquot have a case. It hasnrsquot been a ratings hit either, with viewership dropping as low as  for one episode. Verdict: not utterly pointless, but not likely to become the next Pointless.The NineA team of talented and accomplished presenters, a  minute running time and a news agenda that blends hard-hitting investigations with quirky or thought-provoking items hasnrsquot stopped BBC Scotlandrsquos flagship news programme taking considerable flak from some quarters. Earlier this month one newspaper talked of a ldquotalent exodus from the channel and quoted a BBC insider who called The Nine ldquoa turkey. Damage has undoubtedly been done as a result: negative news stories about behind-the-scenes tensions and potential resignations may not be true, but they contribute to a narrative of failure which becomes hard to shake over time. What is true is that ratings for The Nine have been disappointing on occasions, though in mitigation its time slot doesnrsquot help. Verdict: a rocky start for a potentially stellar offering that may flourish in a dferent time slot.

story: INNERPEFFRAY LIBRARYThe spectacular Library and School at Innerpeffray were founded by David Drummond rd Lord Madertie in around , the first free public lending library in Scotland. Madertie was a member of the Drummond Family, one of the most important landowning families of the area, friend and brother-in-law to James Graham, First Marquis of Montrose.The original library was "partly in the west end of the chapel of Innerpeffray and partly in that little new house lately built by me at the east end of the kirk yard." Making books available to ordinary people free of charge was unprecedented. Madertie wished the library and school to benefit the community "in time coming" and leaving them with a legacy of  Scottish Merks charged his successors with the responsibility.In  Robert Hay Drummond inherited the Innerpeffray estate and responsibility for the Library and School. He raised the funds and commissioned architect Charles Freebairn to design and build a new Library building immediately adjacent to the Chapel. This handsome Georgian edice still houses the library todayBy the nineteenth century the school buildings were dilapidated and a new School and Schoolmasters house were completed in . Pupils came from the surrounding farms and settlements and the school was still in operation until .The Borrowers Register is perhaps the Librarys most valuable book, a handwritten record all the local people to who came to choose a book, and take it home to read. title: andrew-mckie-theresa-may-has-been-the-most-catastrophic-prime-minister-in-modern-times
story: So forgive meI point out that, like Brexit itself, what wersquove got so far is a hollow declaration of intent and not the desired outcome. Theresa May has, so far, announced only that she plans to quit as Tory leader on June , but will remain Prime Minister until her successor is elected , secures the confidence of the Commons and gets rubber-stamped by HM The Queen.On Mrs Mayrsquos track record of promising to leave something, but not managing it, shersquoll still be Tory leader in  and, having fiddled all the rules to get some sort of extension, PM long after the next scheduled General Election. If that appalling state of affairs were to come about, though, she would no doubt insist that it was someone rsquos fault. The EUrsquos fault. The ERGrsquos fault. The Remainersrsquo fault. The votersrsquo fault.:Andrew McKie: Solution to political chaos is as necessary as it is unlikelyNone of that will wash. Itrsquos all her fault. Mrs May is the most catastrophic prime minister since Lord North probably worse. She had lots of room for manoeuvre, as he did not. Thatrsquos a harsh judgment, but itrsquos based on the terms she set, and whichshe was not pushed into, but herself chose. Her dreadfulness is not just a consequence of her own abject failures, but because shersquos made things much more dficult for her successor than they would have been three years ago.Some people think that this judgment is premature, because the next Prime Minister may be even worse. This accords with the narrative ndash popular with Remainers who think the public canrsquot be trusted with a say in their own governance, unless it conforms with the views ofthe political classes ndash that Brexit was an impossible aspiration and any attempt to implement it was bound to be damaging.On this analysis, the worse Mrs Mayrsquos successor fares, the more kindly history will judge her. When whichever of the  Tory MPs standing gets the job, and makes just as big a mess of it, we will see that she was dealt an impossible hand, and played it as well as she could.Irsquom afraid thatrsquos nonsense, too. In poker terms, she was dealt at worst a pair of sixes, and promptly swapped them for seven two offsuit. Those who complain about the lack of specics in the Leave campaign, and a failure to spell out exactly how Brexit would be implemented, canrsquot also maintain that Mrs May had limited options when she emergedas Tory leader in .That would have been that moment at which any halfway capable person would have said: ldquoI promise we will respect the result, but before we go any further, we should establish the terms on which we go, and each of the possibilities involves some trade-offs.Faced with the range of options with which we are now drearily familiar, from Canada +++ to WTO terms, she could have spelt out which might createborder problems in Northern Ireland, restrictions on taking greater control of our agricultural or fisheries, oblige us to continue to abide by EU regulations or ECJ oversight, prevent us from ending unrestricted freedom of movement, and so on.We could even have had, for example, a series of indicative votes in Parliament to see which aspects of Brexit enjoyed enough support to make them worth negotiating for, which were regarded as essential, and which could be conceded in order to protect trade, industry or the financial sector. Did Mrs May even think about any of that  Apparently not.:Andrew McKie: Pointless European elections will just prolong our tormentFor the first nine months or so of her premiership, the only statement we got was ldquoBrexit means Brexit. Unless yoursquore a primary school teacher attempting to explain the reflexive property of the equals sign, this is of limited value in conveying information, evenwe now know that the translation is: ldquoIrsquom not telling you, because I have no idea what Irsquom doing.Worse, the fact that Mrs May didnrsquot know what she was doing didnrsquot stop her from preventing everyone  from pursuing the options. Her succession of Brexit secretaries, who all resigned because she wouldnrsquot let them do their jobs, may have been ndash as the Remain camp naturally claims ndash rubbish, or faced with the impossible. But wersquoll never know, because they never got to negotiate.Instead, at some point, the Prime Minister came up with new definition of Brexit. It was, apparently, a set of red lines. These, as it transpired, were akin to those the teacher puts through the wrong answer, or those used in alarming graphs showing that your approval rating is falling through the floor. And she was dishonest about the limits they created, and theconcessions that she immediately surrendered to Brussels.In part, thatrsquos because of the monomania about immigration she carried over from her time in the Home Office, which immediately ruled out most of the attractive methods of delivering Brexit. But the lessons of Mrs Mayrsquos previous job were not just that she was callous, authoritarian, stubborn, unreasonable and technocratic, though she was all of those. Itrsquos that she didnrsquot even deliverimmigration was her big thing, she failed for  years to do anything about it.A better politician might even have sold her terrible Withdrawal Agreement , but shersquod already proved, in the worst election campaign ever conducted, that she was a terrible politician. Failing to gain a majority against Jeremy Corbyn, Labourrsquos worst and least popular leader ever, was seen, even as her campaign was collapsing almost comically, as an impossibility. Yet she managed it.Itrsquos perfectly possible, perhaps even likely, that the next Prime Minister will prove terrible at delivering a good Brexit, but that shouldnrsquot improve historyrsquos view of Mrs Mayrsquos time in office. Itrsquos her decisions, and hers alone, that have led us to this sorry pass. The only way forward is to acknowledge that every one of them was an error, disown them all, and start again.

story: The Scottish Labour leader also faces calls for an emergency meeting of the partyrsquos ruling body in Scotland which could potentially discuss his future.One party source said no one wanted another leadership contest, but the decline during Mr Leonardrsquos  months in charge was so bad every MP and MSP now feared for their job.Labour, which once dominated Scotland for generations was reduced to fth place in the European election, slumping from  to  per cent of the vote and losing both its MEPs, including David Martin, the UKrsquos longest-serving MEP, who was first elected in .:Tories and Labour panic as election sparks demand for Brexit and indyref votesIt was the partyrsquos worst result north of the border since .Even in the former Labour heartland of Glasgow, Labourrsquos vote fell from  to just %.Two Scottish Labour MPs issued an excoriating public criticism of Mr Leonard, his lieutenants, and the UK Leader Jeremy Corbyn for the partyrsquos disastrous performance.Edinburgh Southrsquos Ian Murray and East Lothianrsquos Martin Whitfield said voters had delivered an ldquoutterly damning verdict on Labourrsquos ambivalence on Brexit, and said of Mr Corbyn and Mr Leonard: ldquoThey stuck their heads in the Brexit sand because they canrsquot lead.Demanding Labour support a Peoplersquos Vote, they said: ldquoIf we fail to listen and learn, our party will never recover.ldquoThey criticised for Mr Leonard, a Corbyn loyalist, for ldquomeekly echoing the UK labour campaign, even putting Mr Corbynrsquos face on leaflets instead of the Scottish leader.They wrote: ldquoThe blame for the worst result in Scottish Labourrsquos history lies squarely with our partyrsquos leadership.ldquoIt is official Labour Party policy to support a Peoplersquos Vote as a way out of this catastrophic mess, yet Jeremy Corbyn snubbed our membership and refused to embrace it.ldquoAs a result, he personally handed victory to Nigel Farage.ldquoThis was Jeremy Corbyn and Richard Leonardrsquos manesto, their message, their decision to ignore the membership and what voters were saying to us.ldquoIt was their election campaign and their mess. They stuck their heads in the Brexit sand because they canrsquot lead.ldquoWe have paid the price for their failure and we have been wiped off the electoral map.ldquoThese results must now act an urgent wake-up call for Richard Leonard, deputy leader Lesley Laird and campaigns manager Neil Findlay.:Scottish Labour MPs slam leadership saying party may lsquonever recoverrsquo from lsquoworst everrsquo resultMr Martin, , said Labour had suffered because of a lack of a clear message on Brexit.He said: ldquoOur message was poor, we didnrsquot really communicate our position and some people might say that is because we donrsquot have one.ldquoIn fairness to Corbyn I think he genuinely thinks he has to deliver on the result of the national referendum, but on the other hand he has seen over the last few years how damaging Brexit is going to be to the country.ldquoHe is trying to ride two horses and it has, of course, proved impossible.He added: ldquoLabourrsquos message from the outset should have been we are the party which wants to keep Scotland in the United Kingdom and keep the UK in Europe, and reform both.Johanna Baxter, a member of Labourrsquos Scottish Executive Committee , said the result reflected a ldquofailure of leadership on the biggest issue to face the country in generations.In a letter to Mr Leonard, she said: ldquoThe SEC is not due to meet again until September.ldquoWe cannot wait until September to address the causes of this defeat. I request that an urgent meeting of the SEC is scheduled as soon as possible to discuss how this position is going to be resolved.Remarkably, Mr Leonard initially responded to the result by issuing a statement that didnrsquot mention Brexit.ldquoThe isions caused by the competing nationalisms of the UK and Scottish Governments continue to be a distraction from both of their failures, he said.ldquoLabour must, and will, do more to challenge these failures and put forward our positive alternatives to invest in our people, our communities and our public services.He later issued an email to party members admitted the public had lost trust in Labour, declaring he now backed ldquothe option to remain and that any Brexit deal should be ratied by a second public vote.However even this appeared to be parroting Mr Corbynrsquos position and relied on a ldquodeal that looks as far away as ever.Scottish Tory leader Ruth Davidson said: ldquoLabourrsquos result was catastrophic for a party that had near hegemony in Scotland in my letime. I donrsquot even know how they answer to that.Scottish LibDem leader Willie Rennie said: ldquoLabour thought they were being smart by trying to bridge the ide when all they were doing was sitting on the fence. It was unclear exactly what they were standing for. I hope the Labour party learn that lesson and back a Peoplersquos Vote so we can put an end to this nonsense.David Clarke, Vice-Chair of the European Movement in Scotland, said: ldquoScottish Labour saw its vote virtually halve to just .%, its worst result ever ndash a direct consequence of its UK leadershiprsquos equivocation over the EU and, above all, a second referendum.ldquoWe therefore call upon UK Labour and the Scottish Labour Party to reverse their stance so far and to openly demand a Peoplersquos Vote, with the option of Remain on the ballot paper.

title: cab-drivers-face-tests-on-english-and-capability-behind-the-wheel
story: Members of Glasgow City Councilrsquos licensing committee are expected to introduce a policy, as suggested by Unite Glasgow Cab Section, which means taxis and private hire car drivers will need to complete an SQA qualication before they can take passengers.In February Konstantinos Theodoropoulos was denied a cab licence in February because he could not identy the City Chambers despite being inside the building opposite.Figures have also revealed the number of complaints made against cab companies in the city has more than doubled in five years.Between  and  the number of incidents rose from  to ,.The number of private hire car drivers has increased, while the councilrsquos licensing committee has dealt with complaints of pirating, cherry-picking hires and over-charging fares.Drivers have also refused to assist wheelchair users or carry guide dogs.A report submitted to the council reveals that the course would cost between pound and pound per driver.While it is hoped the level of customer service will be improved, concerns have been raised by some representatives that the time needed to complete the course could be ldquodetrimental and impact the number of people willing to enter the trade.Alex Wilson, chairman of the licensing board, said: ldquoWe are hoping the qualication will raise the standards of our drivers.ldquoIt is going to replace the existing customer care course which is really outdated.ldquoThe qualication will include a language test and suitable ways to help passengers with disabilities and mental health problems.ldquoThere is already a code of conduct in place for taxi drivers but this new policy will include private hires.ldquoIt will be mandatory for every new driver to complete.ldquoExisting drivers will have to complete it before they renew their licence.:What it feels like to hellip be a night sht Glasgow taxi driverldquoWe want drivers that know their way around Glasgow.ldquoApplicants will have to know where key locations are ndash including the City Chambers.The new SQA qualication will replace the existing customer care course which is considered no longer fit for purpose.A programme was created by the SQA in October last year to help taxi and private hire car drivers adapt to the challenges they face on a daily basis.This certicate in Introduction to the Role of the Professional Taxi and Private Hire Driver at SCQF level  has nine mandatory units.They are: workplace health and safety, safety transport passengers, professional customer service, maintain the safety of the licensed vehicle, mobility and wheelchair assistance, plan routes and fares, transport luggage and parcels, safely transport school age children and the licensing regulations Scotland.From January , , all applicants will require to have completed the training prior to submitting their application. Existing licence holders whose licence needs to be renewed from April , , will need to complete their training before renewing their licence.Warning that standards had been deteriorating, Calum Anderson, of the Glasgow Cab Section, said he was happy that the council had ldquoembraced the unionrsquos idea. He added: ldquoThe standards of private hire car drivers and taxi services are going down. It is ridiculous taxis and cab drivers can gain a licence without a qualication or any training.ldquoIf someone is required to do training, it means they will take time and effort to achieve their qualication.Mr Anderson added: ldquoI am hoping it will deter anyone from coming into the profession for just a casual exercise.ldquoWe want quality not quantity.It is hoped the course will be available by January.

title: nicola-sturgeon-plans-for-indyref2-next-year
story: On a visit to Dublin, the First Minister said her preference was for a vote in the latter half of , and legislation for another vote would be published at Holyrood on Wednesday.Opposition parties accused her of ldquodeceit and of misusing the SNPrsquos win in the European election, which she had insisted was about Brexit.Less than a fortnight ago, Ms Sturgeon said voting SNP was the strongest way to send a message that Scotland wanted to Remain ldquowhether you are for or against independence.The SNP recorded its best ever result in the European election, improving its share of the vote from . to . per cent, and picking up a third MEP to give it half of Scotlandrsquos representation in Brussels.Alyn Smith was re-elected and joined by former MSP Christian Allard and former minister Aileen McLeod, only the SNPrsquos second female MEP after Winnie Ewing.Ms Sturgeon said last month she would bring forward a ldquoframework bill in readiness for a second independence referendum in May, admitting it would need a transfer of power from Westminster to have legal effect.With Theresa May and her successor as prime minister unlikely to grant a Section  order, the referendum bill is essentially a campaign tool for the  Holyrood election.Ms Sturgeonrsquos timetable also indicates the bill is more theatrical than practical, as it implies an unrealistic six to nine-month transition to independence before the election.The First Minister, who met Taoiseach Leo Varadkar during her Irish trip, said the UK Government had treated Scotland with ldquoutter contempt through the Brexit process, while Ireland was respected.She said: ldquoSuddenly this idea of being a small independent country in the European Union, we only have to look at Ireland to see the benefits of that and many people are having their eyes opened.ldquoThere will be another Scottish independence referendum and I will make a prediction today that Scotland will vote for independence and we will become an independent country just like Ireland, and the strong relationship between our two countries now will become even stronger soon.ldquoI want to see Scotland having the choice of independence within this term of the Scottish Parliament, which ends in May , so towards the latter half of next year would be when I think is the right time for that choice.In a separate BBC interview, she added: ldquoThis week we will bring forward legislation to put in place the rules for giving people the choice in an independence referendum over a Brexit future or a future as an independent European nation.Speaking to the media at Edinburgh City Chambers, where the results for Scotland were confirmed after the Western Isles declared on Monday morning, Mr Smyth also said Scots wanted to stop Brexit andthat didnrsquot happen independence was ldquoback on the table.He said: ldquoWe reserve all our rights to do whatrsquos necessary for Scotlandrsquos best interests. So the independence question is back on the table, as it has been since the EU referendum.ldquoWe donrsquot want to see Scotland dragged out of the EU against our will.ldquoWe were told in  we were a partnership of nations, a partnership of equals, wersquore now being told to shut up and get to the back of the bus.ldquoThe people want better than that and they deserve better than that.SNP Westminster leader Ian Blackford said the election result had cemented the SNPrsquos case for another referendum in the event of a no-deal Brexit.Scottish Tory MSP Maurice Golden said: ldquoThe SNP went into this election pretending to voters that it was nothing to do with independence. Yet within hours of it being announced, Nicola Sturgeon is specically using it to argue for separation.ldquoThatrsquos fraudulent behaviour from an SNP Government thatrsquos meant to be running the country, not trying to break it up. Voters punished Nicola Sturgeon last time she abused the Brexit process for her own selfish aims.ldquoThey will do so againthis hypocritical deceit continues.Scottish LibDem leader Willie Rennie said Ms Sturgeon had told Unionists they ldquocould vote for the SNP with no fear of that vote being misused. I donrsquot think people will appreciate this.ldquoShe tried to say that everyone who voted Remain in the referendum had somehow indicated support for independence, and she misjudged that.ldquoShe shouldnrsquot misjudge this one as well. ldquoThis is about stopping Brexit. Thatrsquos the top priority.Chief executive of Scotland in Union Pamela Nash said: ldquoThe SNP is utterly shameless. Nicola Sturgeon appealed to pro-UK voters to back her in this election, but as soon as the votes are counted the SNP reverts to type to claim a fresh mandate for an unwanted and isive second independence referendum.ldquoThis election was not about independence, which we know is only supported by a minority of people in Scotland.ldquoBut itrsquos a stark reminder that the SNP will never stop campaigning to ide us, which is why we must also continue to campaign for a better future for Scotland as part of the UK.

title: the-best-and-worst-of-times-in-a-tale-of-two-cities
story: The gurgling sound you hear is those words sticking in the throat of a born and bred Aberdonian. In this modern tale of two cities, therersquos little doubt which one can look forward to the best of times.In contrast, Aberdeen has failed to exploit the advantages bestowed by geological and geographical accident. Oil and gas brought unprecedented wealth and prosperity to the North East. The evidence is still here from over-priced housing to the infestation of x vehicles designed to combat kangaroos in the Australian outback, but now choking city roads.The bonanza brought personal prosperity to many. Unfortunately, it also created arrogant complacency that ignores the finite nature of oil and gas. The absence of civic vision and investment is immediately obvious, even to the casual visitor. The city centre is dispirited and downtrodden. Aberdeen may well be unique amongst the worldrsquos ldquoenergy hubs in its failure to exploit the windfall to enhance its appearance, facilities and cultural le.Having lived in the Aberdeen area all my le, I cannot name a single building of architectural merit constructed in that time. When presented with an open goal to enhance two of the cityrsquos most important historical buildings, the council again missed the target, opting for another nondescript retail development.Sure, it can be argued that the new concert, conference and exhibition hub nearing completion is a symbol of the cityrsquos ambition. Yet, itrsquos unlikely to generate the community and grassroots involvement that is the strength of DCA. As my late mother would have put it, ldquoFur coat and nae knickers.Read more: VA Dundee hits half million visitors six months ahead of scheduleAberdeenrsquos efforts at development have lacked the synergy that is evident on Tayside. Dundee has recovered from the loss of its principal industries by coordinating and building on modern strengths. The technologies of the st century have replaced the printing presses, looms and production lines.The interrelationship of education, entrepreneurship, creativity, design and technology has laid the foundations of Dundeersquos economic recovery and regeneration. The critical synergy is embodied in the success of enterprises such as J Studios, the brainchild of entrepreneurs Paddy Burns and Chris van der Kuyl. In turn that is helping drive the -year, pound billion Waterfront development.Those of us who love Aberdeen and care deeply about its future cannot help but worry about what lies ahead. There is little evidence of a coherent economic strategy when the well runs dry. The regionrsquos economy is still very much a one trick pony and to date there is little sign of the forward thinking and ersication evident on Tayside.Aberdeen has been poorly served by administrations of ying political hues. The Scottish Government however, is not blameless for the lack of a Plan B for the Granite City. Aberdeen has been consistently short-changed by central governmentrsquos annual funding allocation. The Scottish Government rightly berated successive UK administrations for their failure to establish an equivalent of the  trillion Norwegian Sovereign Fund. The fund has enabled Norwegians to invest their metaphorical and literal fortune for the benefit of present and future generations.The Scottish Government is failing to secure the future of the Aberdeen area. Millions have flowed from the area to fund developments in the central belt and beyond. Damnably little has been re -invested to prepare Aberdeen for le after oil. While the much-delayed Aberdeen bypass was welcome, Aberdeen was bypassed long before the road was complete.Itrsquos still not too late. Oil and gas will flow from the North Sea for years yet. Local and national politicians can still make the case for a north-east sovereign fund to secure the arearsquos economic and cultural future. They could do worse than follow the road and miles to Dundee.

title: letters-did-brexit-party-voters-know-what-they-were-endorsing
story: There is no doubt that many who cast their vote for the Brexit Party did so as a traditional form of protest to demonstrate their displeasure with the way the Brexit process has been manhandled by both the Conservative and Labour parties. However, there is evidence to suggest that traditional loyalties to mainstream political groups have experienced a signicant sht as voter frustration with the perceived torpor of the historic two main partiescontinues to grow.Regardless of why they voted for the Brexit Party, I presume that those who did are aware of the partys broad aims and policies, even although they have no manesto.The Brexit Party is essentially a company that masquerades as a populist group centred on a leadership cult. Many media outlets believe the group is funded by dark money with the businessman, Arron Banks, acting as puppet master to the narcissistic Mr Farage. The original leader, Catherine Blaiklock, resigned in March of this year after posting Islamophobic comments online. Shortly afterwards, the party treasurer Michael McGough also resigned following anti-Semitic and homophobic social media posts.Though Mr Farage attempts to adopt a veneer of respectability, the party is essentially xenophobic and racist, mirroring much of the European far-right parties at present. He is an opportunist with short-term soundbites but no long-term economic or social strategy. Mr Farage thrives on chaos and disorder and, like most extremists, only presents as a solution in times of desperation and despair.The partys constitution advocates lowering of taxation for the wealthy and a desire to diminish the role of the state, in short, a dismantling of the NHS, the eradication of or swingeing cuts to benefits and an Americanisation of workers rights.If you did decide to vote for the Brexit Party under the disingenuous guise that the referendum result must be honoured above all commonsense then so be it. However, those who live by pseudo-democratic principles may also die by them.Owen Kelly, Stirling.PARTY in government in Westminsterndash fth in the EU elections party in government in Scotlandndash first in EU Elections. What a contrast and a clear endorsement of the clear message from the SNP on Brexit.But what about those that followed the SNP in the polls here in Scotland, breathtakingly in second place came the Brexit Party, with the LibDems having a slight renaissance in third place. The two main parties at Westminster the Conservativesand Labourboth suffered the same results in Scotland as they did in the rest of the UK ndash disastrous, begging the question: do they have a future in Scotland Those results for the Conservatives and Labour in normal circumstances would see instant resignations by their leaders . We have already had the resignation timetable from the PM, but what about Labour Leader Jeremy Corbyn, surely his departure must also be imminent  Those results clearly send a message to Westminster: it cannot be business as usual with more of the same.Scotland in confirming her result of  to Remain, demands Article  is revoked.Catriona C Clark, Falkirk.EARLIER this month Dr Gerald Edwards, in one of his regular anti-SNP musings, forecast that after the European elections ldquoMs Sturgeon could well be in a very exposed situation in a weekrsquos time . My point is not that Dr Edwards got his forecast wildly wrong, but that he ndash and his fellow scribes ndash continue to deny all the evidence that points to the realities of the political situation in Scotland.Out of  council areas in Scotland, the SNP won . The polls indicated that the SNP would do well, but Dr Edwards took no account of them. Today, the Stirling Tories announce on social media that ldquotheyrsquovegone nowhere from their  General Election result. Well, in the European elections the SNP is polling  per cent, the highest share of the vote for any party in the UK. It has increased its seats from two to three. The Conservatives polled . per cent , Labour . per cent.Ruth Davidson announced: ldquoYour vote for myScottish Conservative and Unionist team will tell Nicola Sturgeon no more referendums. The voting in Ms Davidsonrsquos constituency was SNP  per cent, Conservatives  per cent.Before the frenetic spinning starts to show what a bad result it was for the SNP, both Conservatives and Labour should reflect on the realities of what the people of Scotland want. It might even benefit these parties to show that they really can listen to ldquothe people.Hamish McPherson, Gfnock.NICOLA Sturgeon appears to suggest the prospect of a new Prime Minister she doesnt like, such as Boris Johnson, adds credence to her ambition to end a -plus years political, economic, cultural and social union. What nonsense ndash politicians come and go, thankfully. Many in Scotland remain distinctly unimpressed by Ms Sturgeon as First Minister and her relentless isive narrative, but presumably dont believe that justies ending devolution and closing Holyrood.Martin Redfern, Edinburgh EH.THE turnout for the EU elections in the UK is a disgrace. It is signicantly better across the EU. though not exactly an endorsement of the democratic process. To argue in Britain that there was no point, presumably because we are leaving the EU anyway, shows an astonishing indference to the opportunity to show our feelings about the Brexit process, whether for or against. In the absence of a promised second referendum, this was an opportunity to be heard again.The Brexit Party is billed as the victor, though more voters chose Remain parties. Worse, this apparent victory will be used to justy a hard Brexit, which presumably, all those who did not cast a vote, dont mind.Where is leadership in this debacle  Where is the champion to counter the voice of empty populism  I despair.Trevor Rigg, Edinburgh EH.

title: focus-must-be-on-economy-not-independence-says-think-tank
story: A study by Reform Scotland calls for political parties to focus on the economy in the next Holyrood election, arguing it is the ldquosingle most important issue facing the country.:Nicola Sturgeon plans for indyref next yearThe report concludes the Scottish economy ldquois now so erse that greater devolution of power to local authorities is essential for the nation to fulfil its potential.Adding to its calls for further powers for councils, the independent think tank suggested they could make changes to council tax at a local level, have full control over non-domestic rates and have the powers to introduce new taxes and elected regional mayors.Reform Scotland director Chris Deerin said: ldquoWe cannot realistically expect our political parties to forget about the constitutional debate as we head towards the  elections.ldquoHowever, we should expect them to understand and reflect that the single most important issue facing Scotland is its economic performance.ldquoScotland has signicant economic strengths and weaknesses.:Nigel Farage did not win, and another election is now much more likelyldquoSome of those weaknesses are global problems which will largely require global solutions but others are very local problems which, similarly, require very local solutions.He added: ldquoThose local solutions are, at present, impossible to access, because Scotlandrsquos local authorities are insufficiently equipped. We talk, frequently, about the devolution of power from Westminster to Holyrood. That devolution should not have stopped at Edinburgh.ldquoTo realise the economic and social potential of all of Scotland, Edinburgh must let go.

title: edinburgh-and-glasgow-airport-amongst-worst-for-flight-delays-in-the-uk
story: Edinburgh Airport and Glasgow Airport finished joint seventh on the list with average delays for departures of  minutes each according to the Civil Aviation Authority.:Holiday flight chaos looms as airport staff to strikeThey were the only Scottish airports have featured on the list.London Stansted is the fourth busiest airport in the UK. Itwas the worst UK airport for flight delays last year, an investigation has found.A consumer group described the figure as ldquocompletely unacceptable.It is a hub for a number of low-cost eastern European airlines as well as being the largest base for Ryanair.Departures from the Essex airport were an average of  minutes late in , according to Press Association analysis of Civil Aviation Authority data.:First look: New pound.m lounge at Glasgow Airport set to open this summerBirmingham and London Luton recorded the joint second worst punctuality performance, with aircraft typically taking off  minutes behind schedule.The ranking takes into account every scheduled and chartered flight from  major UK airports. Cancelled flights are not included.Flights across all featured airports were delayed by an average of  minutes in .Belfast Cityrecorded the best performance with a figure of just eight minutes.Liverpoolwas in second place , followed by Doncaster Sheffield, Exeter and Bournemouth .Rory Boland, editor of consumer magazine Which  Travel, said: ldquoItrsquos completely unacceptable for passengers to be regularly delayed by nearly half an hour.ldquoThese delays arenrsquot just an inconvenience but can leave holidaymakers hundreds of pounds out of pocket because of missed connections, transfers and fines for picking up their hire car late.ldquoWhile compensation is available for delays of over three hours, airlines should stop passing the buck and make it easier for their passengers by finally introducing automatic compensation.A spokesman for London Stansted said: ldquoFollowing a particularly challenging summer last year when adverse weather and air traffic control issues had a dramatic impact on airline on-time performance, Ryanair committed to a multimillion-pound investment in additional resourcing and equipment to support its ground operation at London Stansted.ldquoThis investment has already helped deliver signicant service improvements to flight punctuality.Trade body the Airport Operators Associationsaid delays are caused by a ldquorange of factors.Last year featured a blast of cold weather due to the Beast from the East and strikes by air traffic controllers in countries such as France and Belgium.The AOA added that disruption is also caused by the capacity of UK airspace being constrained.The aviation industry is working with the Department for Transport to modernise the way flights are managed to improve resilience and boost capacity.

title: smacking-ban-a-positive-and-necessary-step-says-msp
story: A memberrsquos Bill has been put forward at Holyrood by Scottish Green MSP John Finnie which would remove the defence of ldquojustiable assault in Scots law, which allows parents to use physical punishment on children.:Smacking ban lsquowill do nothing to help vulnerable childrenrsquoThe move has been backed by a majority of MSPs on the Scottish Parliamentrsquos Equalities and Human Rights Committee, howeversome campaigners have suggested it could lead to criminalisation of parents.Another voice joins #ParentsforEqualProtection. If you support @JohnFinnieHI Bill to end physical punishment of children, wed love to hear about ithellip pic NFpRlDKPwmdash Children stMay , Mr Finnie stated that the change would bring Scotland into line with best practice from around the world.He said: ldquoMSPs from all five parties supported my original proposal and the recent report published by the Equalities and Human Rights Committee highlighted that affording children equal protection will bring substantial benefits to iniduals and society.ldquoFty-four countries already prohibit the physical punishment of children, with all the evidence showing that this is a positive and necessary step.ldquoIf passed my Bill will bring Scotland into line with international best practice. I look forward to progressing it through the parliamentary process.Mr Finnie will lead a debate on his proposal at Holyrood on Tuesday, with MSPs asked to vote on whether they agree with the general principles of Mr Finniersquos Bill.Campaigners who are in support of the Bill are also expected to gather outside the parliament on Tuesday morning.Mary Glasgow, from the childrenrsquos charity Children st, said: ldquoCivic Scotland has sent a resounding message to MSPs ndash we can no longer tolerate the physical punishment of any child.ldquoMany countries, most recently Ireland, have already changed their law ndash itrsquos time Scotland caught up.:Smacking ban can change attitudes towards violenceMatt Forde, NSPCC Scotland, said: ldquoItrsquos wrong that children in Scotland have less protection from assault and that a legal defence which does not exist when an adult is hit can be used to justy striking a child.ldquoWe strongly believe a change in the law is a common-sense move. Closing this loophole brings Scotland in line with dozens of countries across the world and is simply about fairness and equality for our children.In an open letter published last week,a group of academics, parenting experts and campaigners urged MSPs to oppose the Bill.On Tuesday  May, MSPs will debate and vote on the smacking Bill for the first time. Email your MSP and tell them your views. #WeTrustParents pic xpCZubKLmdash Be ReasonableMay , They suggested that the Bill would do nothing to help vulnerable children and could risk criminalising parents.ldquoWe are deeply concerned by legislation before the Scottish Parliament to remove the defence of reasonable chastisement and introduce a lsquosmacking banrsquo, they wrote.ldquoIt is unnecessary, will do nothing to help vulnerable children and will instead cause traumatic intervention in good families.ldquoThe discourse around smacking is dishonest. It conflates lsquohittingrsquo and violence with smacking.ldquoBut violence against children is already outlawed under current legislation.It added:ldquoRemoving the defence will leave loving parents open to police cautions and even criminal convictions for behaviour which is, by definition, lsquoreasonablersquo.ldquoThe stress this would bring to parents and children far outweighs any perceived benefits.ldquoA smacking ban would also make the work of the police and social services more dficult by bringing hundreds of good parents under the remit of child protection agencies, impeding efforts to identy actual abuse.ldquoThe vast majority of Scots do not want to see smacking criminalised, regardless of their views on smacking as a parenting technique.ldquoWe urge MSPs to oppose this legislation when it is debated.
